Option B) Olanzapine. Olanzapine is an atypical antipsychotic used primarily for the treatment of schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. It is not typically used for the management of Alzheimer's disease and can have adverse effects, including worsening cognitive function in elderly dementia patients.

 

Option C) Lorazepam. Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine used for anxiety, insomnia, and agitation. It is not recommended for long-term use in managing Alzheimer's disease due to the risk of cognitive impairment, dependence, and increased risk of falls.

 

Option D) Memantine. Memantine is an NMDA receptor antagonist used in the treatment of moderate to severe Alzheimer's disease. It could be considered for this patient if her disease was more advanced; however, Donepezil is generally preferred for initial therapy in mild to moderate cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The role of Donepezil in the management of Alzheimer's disease – It is important to recognize that Donepezil, a cholinesterase inhibitor, is indicated for mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease to enhance cognitive function.
  • Differentiating between the use of Donepezil and other medications not primarily indicated for Alzheimer's disease, such as antipsychotics and benzodiazepines, is crucial for safe and effective patient care.

questions.text: Identify this instrument shown in the image which is placed vaginally and is used to elevate the fetal head in a difficult cesarean section where the head is deeply engaged:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fetal pillow

 

  • In a deeply engaged head, delivery at cesarean can be difficult and can cause extension of the incisions and bleeding.
  • Several methods have been identified to facilitate delivery of a deeply engaged head. These include
    1. Fetal pillow
    2. An assistant pushes the head up from below
    3. Delivery by Patwardhan maneuver (Delivering the shoulders then the breech then pulling out the head) as shown below

 

Patwardhan maneuver

 

Ref: Page no 1430, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text:
Which of the following cause(s) vasodilation in the pulmonary vessels?

 

  1. Endothelin
  2. Bradykinin
  3. Nitric oxide
  4. Thromboxane
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 3

 

  • In the pulmonary circulation, bradykinin and nitric oxide have vasodilatory effects on the blood vessels.
  • Prostacyclin will also cause vasodilation in the pulmonary vasculature.
  • Endothelin and thromboxane will cause vasoconstriction of the pulmonary blood vessels.
  • The other factors causing pulmonary vasoconstriction are alveolar hypoxia, norepinephrine and alpha-adrenergic agonists.

 

Ref: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 2nd South Asia edition, page no.358

questions.text: During a labor and delivery rotation, a third-year medical resident is called to assist with a challenging vaginal delivery. The patient is a 30-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, who has been in labor for 12 hours. The fetal head has crowned, but progress has halted due to shoulder dystocia. The obstetric team is preparing to intervene to safely deliver the baby. The resident recalls the various maneuvers used to resolve shoulder dystocia and considers the initial step to take in this situation. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial maneuver to address this shoulder dystocia?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) McRoberts maneuver

 

Explanation:

 

The McRoberts maneuver is a commonly used and effective first-line intervention for shoulder dystocia. It involves sharply flexing the mother's legs toward her chest, which flattens the sacrum and changes the angle of the pelvis, often allowing the anterior shoulder to dislodge from behind the pubic symphysis. This maneuver is non-invasive, can be quickly implemented, and has a high success rate, making it the preferred initial approach in cases of shoulder dystocia.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Suprapubic pressure (A): While this can be an effective technique, it is usually employed concurrently with or after the McRoberts maneuver. It involves applying pressure just above the pubic bone to help dislodge the fetal shoulder.
  • Delivery of the posterior arm (B): This is a more invasive procedure and is considered if the initial, less invasive maneuvers (like the McRoberts maneuver and suprapubic pressure) fail. It involves reaching into the birth canal to locate and deliver the posterior arm of the fetus.
  • Episiotomy (D): Although episiotomy can provide more space for manipulations, it is not a direct maneuver to relieve shoulder dystocia and is considered more of an adjunctive procedure to facilitate other maneuvers if needed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The question aims to test the knowledge of immediate management steps for shoulder dystocia during delivery. The McRoberts maneuver is highlighted as the first-line intervention due to its simplicity, safety, and effectiveness. Understanding the sequence and rationale behind maneuvers for shoulder dystocia is crucial for safely managing this obstetric emergency and minimizing the risk of complications for both the mother and the newborn.

questions.text: An obese diabetic patient was on metformin monotherapy, but his sugar levels were not well controlled. He is allergic to sulfa drugs and does not comply with injectable drugs. He has a history of pancreatitis, and family history of bladder carcinoma. In view of the raised glucose levels, you wish to add another anti-diabetic drug. Which one would you prefer?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Canagliflozin

 

The answer to this question can be known by ruling out three options.

 

  • Liraglutide is an injectable drug (name ends with tide), so cannot be the answer.
  • Sitagliptin can cause pancreatitis, so would not be preferred in a patient with history of pancreatitis.
  • Pioglitazone increases the risk of urinary bladder carcinoma, therefore contra-indicated in patients with increased risk of this cancer (in this patient, there is family history).
  • So, by ruling out, canagliflozin becomes the answer to this question.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the emergency department following a high-speed motorcycle accident. He complains of severe pain in his lower extremity, particularly around the knee. On examination, there is a large, fluctuant, and ecchymotic area on the lateral aspect of his thigh extending to the knee. The skin over the area is intact, but there is a palpable fluid collection beneath the skin that shifts with pressure. Imaging studies are ordered to assess for underlying fractures and to further evaluate the soft tissue swelling. Which of the following injuries is most likely associated with the described soft tissue finding, known as a Morel-Lavallee lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acetabular fracture

 

  • A Morel-Lavallee lesion is a closed degloving injury that occurs when shearing forces cause the skin and subcutaneous tissues to separate from the underlying fascia, leading to the accumulation of blood, lymph, and necrotic fat in the potential space created.
  • This lesion is most commonly associated with high-energy trauma and can occur in conjunction with pelvic and acetabular fractures due to the significant forces involved in such injuries.
  • In the case of an acetabular fracture, the mechanism of injury often involves a direct blow to the hip region, such as from a motor vehicle accident or a fall from height, which can generate the shearing forces necessary to produce a Morel-Lavallee lesion.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Fracture of the femoral neck. While femoral neck fractures can occur due to high-energy trauma, especially in younger patients, they are less frequently associated with Morel-Lavallee lesions compared to pelvic injuries. The mechanism and location of injury typically differ.

 

Option C. Fracture of the lumbar spine. Lumbar spine fractures result from mechanisms such as falls, direct impacts, or axial loads, which are different from the shearing forces typically responsible for Morel-Lavallee lesions. These lesions are more commonly associated with injuries around the pelvis and lower extremities.

 

Option D. Fracture of the proximal tibia. Although proximal tibial fractures can occur with high-energy trauma and could be associated with Morel-Lavallee lesions, especially when the trauma involves shearing forces, the most classic association is with pelvic and acetabular fractures due to the nature of the forces involved and the anatomical structures at risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The educational objective is to identify Morel-Lavallee lesions as closed degloving injuries that are most classically associated with high-energy trauma to the pelvic region, particularly with acetabular fractures.
  • Understanding the relationship between the mechanism of injury and the development of this lesion is essential for the accurate diagnosis and management of patients presenting with trauma to the hip and pelvic regions.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman presents to her obstetrician after being exposed to a confirmed case of rubella. She is concerned about the risk to her unborn child and inquires about post-exposure prophylaxis. Her obstetrician discusses the option of administering rubella immunoglobulin to reduce the risk of contracting the infection. What is the recommended dose of rubella immunoglobulin for post-exposure prophylaxis in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 20 mL

 

Explanation: The recommended dose of rubella immunoglobulin for post-exposure prophylaxis in adults, particularly in high-risk situations such as exposure during pregnancy, is 20 mL. This dose aims to provide passive immunity to the rubella virus, potentially preventing infection or modifying its course, thereby reducing the risk of congenital rubella syndrome in the fetus.

 

Educational Objective

 

IMMUNOGLOBULIN DOSAGES

choices.text: Graves' disease
Endemic iodine deficiency
Subacute thyroiditis
HCG-induced thyrotoxicosis

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with palpitations, weight loss, and heat intolerance. Physical examination reveals a slightly enlarged thyroid gland, tachycardia, and fine tremors in the hands. Laboratory tests show a low thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level and elevated free thyroxine (T4) and triiodothyronine (T3) levels. Radioactive iodine uptake scan of the patient showed the following result. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Graves' disease

 

  • The given image shows diffusely increased uptake homogeneously suggestive of Graves’ disease.
  • Graves' disease is an autoimmune disorder that is the most common cause of hyperthyroidism.
  • It is characterized by the presence of autoantibodies that stimulate the thyroid gland to produce excessive thyroid hormone.
  • The key features that support this diagnosis include symptoms of hyperthyroidism (palpitations, weight loss, heat intolerance), physical findings (thyroid enlargement, tachycardia, fine hand tremors), and laboratory results (low TSH with high free T4 and T3).
  • The radioactive iodine uptake scan typically shows diffuse high uptake throughout the gland (homogeneously) due to increased synthesis and release of thyroid hormones, which is consistent with the image provided.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Endemic iodine deficiency. This condition leads to hypothyroidism rather than hyperthyroidism, and the thyroid uptake scan would not show increased uptake as seen in the image.

 

Option C. Subacute thyroiditis. This condition is usually a self-limited inflammation of the thyroid gland, often following a viral infection. It may cause temporary hyperthyroidism, but the radioactive iodine uptake is typically low or normal since the gland is releasing preformed hormones rather than producing more.

 

Option D. HCG-induced thyrotoxicosis. This condition occurs when high levels of human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG), as seen in pregnancy or molar pregnancies, stimulate the thyroid. This would not typically cause an enlarged thyroid gland and would show a different pattern on the uptake scan.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Schematic showing thyroid scan appearance in various conditions:

choices.text: Sensitivity is less than specificity
Sensitivity is the same as specificity
Positive Predictive Value (PPV) is more than Negative Predictive Value (NPV)
PPV is the same as NPV

questions.text:
A study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a new ECG algorithm in diagnosing myocardial infarction (MI). The table below summarizes the results:

 

 

Based on the data, which of the following statements is true regarding the diagnostic performance of the ECG algorithm?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) PPV is the same as NPV

 

Explanation:

 

Calculations:

 

  • Sensitivity = True Positives / (True Positives + False Negatives) = 300 / (300 + 25) = 92%
  • Specificity = True Negatives / (True Negatives + False Positives) = 75 / (75 + 100) = 43%
  • Positive Predictive Value (PPV) = True Positives / (True Positives + False Positives) = 300 / (300 + 100) = 75%
  • Negative Predictive Value (NPV) = True Negatives / (True Negatives + False Negatives) = 75 / (75 + 25) = 75%

 

The Positive Predictive Value (PPV) and Negative Predictive Value (NPV) both measure the algorithm's accuracy, with PPV indicating the probability that a positive test correctly identifies an MI and NPV indicating the probability that a negative test correctly identifies the absence of an MI. In this case, both PPV and NPV are calculated as 75%, indicating equal reliability in predicting true positives and true negatives.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option (a) Sensitivity is less than specificity: This is incorrect because sensitivity (92%) is higher than specificity (43%), indicating the algorithm is better at identifying true positives than true negatives.
  • Option (b) Sensitivity is the same as specificity: This is incorrect as the calculated sensitivity and specificity are different, reflecting the algorithm's varying effectiveness in identifying true positives and true negatives.
  • Option (c) PPV is more than NPV: This is incorrect as both PPV and NPV are calculated to be 75%, showing equal effectiveness in positive and negative predictions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Specificity of a screening test is the ability of a test to detect: True negatives.
  • Sensitivity of a screening test is the ability of a test to detect: True positives
  • ‘Usefulness of a screening test’ is given by: Sensitivity
  • Statistical index of diagnostic accuracy: Sensitivity
  • Out of those shown positive by a screening test in a population, those who actually have the disease, this is: PPV of a screening test
  • Out of those shown negative by a screening test in a population, those who actually do not have the disease.

choices.text: Mutations in the proteins on the bacterial surface
Changes in the membrane permeability to penicillin
Production of an alternative penicillin-binding protein

questions.text: In the management of a community-acquired pneumonia case, a 55-year-old man with no significant past medical history is found to be infected with Streptococcus pneumoniae. Despite initial treatment with penicillin, the patient shows minimal improvement. Further laboratory tests indicate that the strain of S. pneumoniae is resistant to penicillin. Considering the mechanism of resistance in Streptococcus pneumoniae, which of the following best explains the observed resistance in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Production of an alternative penicillin-binding protein

 

  • The primary mechanism by which Streptococcus pneumoniae develops resistance to penicillin is through the production of altered penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs).
  • These altered PBPs have a lower affinity for penicillin, allowing the bacterium to synthesize its cell wall even in the presence of the antibiotic, thereby rendering penicillin ineffective.
  • This mechanism is a result of genetic mutations and is the most common cause of penicillin resistance in S. pneumoniae.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Production of Beta-lactamase. Streptococcus pneumoniae typically does not produce Beta-lactamase as a mechanism of resistance to penicillin. This mechanism is more commonly associated with bacteria like Staphylococcus aureus.

 

Option B. Mutations in the proteins on the bacterial surface. While mutations can confer resistance in various ways, in the case of S. pneumoniae and penicillin resistance, alterations in surface proteins are not the primary mechanism.

 

Option C. Changes in the membrane permeability to penicillin. Changes in membrane permeability can indeed lead to antibiotic resistance in some bacterial species. However, this is not the primary mechanism by which S. pneumoniae develops resistance to penicillin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mechanism of penicillin resistance in Streptococcus pneumoniae is due to the production of altered penicillin-binding proteins, leading to a decreased affinity for the drug.

choices.text: It is seen only in immunocompromised individuals.
May be associated with pneumatocele formation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with a history of HIV/AIDS presents to the emergency department with a 3-week history of progressive dyspnea, non-productive cough, and fever. His CD4 count is 50 cells/mm³, and he has not been adherent to his antiretroviral therapy. A chest X-ray reveals bilateral interstitial infiltrates. Given the patient's immunocompromised state and clinical presentation, a diagnosis of Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PJP) is considered. Which of the following statements about P. jirovecii infection is FALSE?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is seen only in immunocompromised individuals.

 

  • While P. jirovecii pneumonia (PJP) is most commonly seen in immunocompromised individuals, particularly those with HIV/AIDS, it is not exclusively seen in this population.
  • Asymptomatic colonization can occur in immunocompetent individuals, and PJP can also cause disease in other immunosuppressed populations, such as organ transplant recipients or those on chronic corticosteroid therapy.
  • Therefore, the statement that P. jirovecii is seen only in immunocompromised individuals is false.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Frequently associated with CMV (Cytomegalovirus). Pneumocystis jirovecii infection may coexist with other opportunistic infections in immunocompromised patients, including CMV. However, the statement "frequently associated" could be misleading, as not all P. jirovecii infections are accompanied by CMV.

 

Option C. May be associated with pneumatocele formation. Pneumocystis jirovecii can cause pneumatoceles, which are cystic air spaces that develop in the lung due to the damage caused by the infection. This statement is true and describes one of the possible complications of P. jirovecii pneumonia.

 

Option D. Diagnosed with sputum microscopy. Pneumocystis jirovecii can indeed be diagnosed using sputum microscopy, particularly using special stains such as Gomori methenamine silver or immunofluorescence assays, which can detect the cysts or trophic forms of the organism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • While P. jirovecii is a significant cause of pneumonia in the immunocompromised, it can also colonize the lungs of healthy individuals without causing illness.
  • This understanding is important for accurate diagnosis and treatment of Pneumocystis pneumonia, especially in patients with weakened immune systems.

choices.text: CECT with oral contrast

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of peptic ulcer disease presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain, distension, and vomiting for the past 24 hours. He reports that the pain started suddenly and has been getting progressively worse. He has not had a bowel movement or passed gas in over 12 hours. On examination, the patient appears to be in severe distress, with a distended and tender abdomen. He has a fever of 39°C, and his blood pressure is low at 90/60 mmHg. Blood tests show an elevated white blood cell count. Which of the following would be detrimental in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Barium meal

 

  • In this case, the most detrimental option would be Barium meal.
  • The patient's presentation with sudden onset severe abdominal pain, distention, vomiting, absence of bowel movements or gas, fever, hypotension, and leukocytosis is highly suggestive of a perforated viscus, possibly secondary to peptic ulcer disease.
  • In the setting of suspected gastrointestinal perforation, the use of barium as a contrast agent is contraindicated because if barium escapes into the peritoneal cavity through a perforation, it can cause barium peritonitis, a life-threatening condition.
  • Barium peritonitis is associated with high morbidity and mortality rates due to the intense inflammatory reaction barium causes when it contacts the peritoneal surfaces.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. CECT (Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography). This is a highly valuable diagnostic tool in this scenario, as it can help identify the site of perforation, the presence of free air, and other complications. It does not require the administration of oral contrast and can be performed rapidly, making it suitable for emergency situations.

 

Option B. CECT with oral contrast. While not typically necessary for the initial diagnosis of a perforated viscus, CECT with oral contrast can sometimes be used to more precisely localize a perforation site or to assess for complications such as abscess formation. However, in acute settings with unstable patients, it's often skipped to expedite diagnosis and treatment.

 

Option C. Gastrograffin study. Gastrograffin (water-soluble contrast) studies can be used in certain situations to assess for gastrointestinal perforation, as gastrograffin is less irritating to the peritoneum than barium. However, its use is generally reserved for specific indications and may not be the first-line imaging study in an emergency setting with a suspected perforated viscus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The educational objective is to understand the appropriate and inappropriate use of imaging contrasts in the setting of suspected gastrointestinal perforation.
  • Barium meal is contraindicated in cases of suspected perforation due to the risk of barium peritonitis, which can exacerbate the patient's condition and increase morbidity and mortality.
  • Other imaging modalities like CECT (with or without oral contrast) and Gastrograffin studies have their specific roles and must be chosen based on the clinical context and the information needed for diagnosis and management.

questions.text: In a workshop, focused on crime scene investigation techniques, a forensic expert is demonstrating the use of various types of lights to detect biological evidence that is not visible to the naked eye. One part of the demonstration involves the identification of seminal stains, which are often crucial in sexual assault cases. The expert explains the importance of choosing the appropriate type of light to enhance the visibility of such stains for collection and analysis. Which type of light should the forensic expert use to visualize invisible or faint seminal stains at the crime scene?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) UV light

 

  • UV light, also known as ultraviolet light, is commonly used in forensic investigations to detect bodily fluids, including seminal stains, that are not visible under normal lighting conditions.
  • Seminal fluid fluoresces under UV light, making it easier for forensic experts to identify and collect evidence from a crime scene.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Infrared. Infrared light is not typically used for visualizing seminal stains as it does not cause the required fluorescence for detection.

 

Option C. Dark illumination. Not used in forensic investigations for the visualization of stains.

 

Option D. Red light. Red light does not have the properties to make seminal stains visible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Seminal fluid examination: (Physical examination) dry seminal stains are greyish-white in colour and under UV light show bluish-white fluorescence due to presence of choline.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man presents with a complaint of loss of sensation while shaving, which he noticed after undergoing a parotidectomy. He reports no facial weakness or difficulty in chewing but is concerned about the numbness affecting his daily routine. Physical examination reveals an intact motor function of the facial muscles and normal jaw movement. Based on the surgical history and the patient's symptoms, which nerve is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Greater auricular nerve

 

  • The greater auricular nerve, a branch of the cervical plexus, is most likely affected in this patient.
  • It provides sensory innervation to the skin over the parotid gland, the mastoid process, and the back of the auricle.
  • During parotidectomy, the greater auricular nerve is at risk of injury due to its location and course over the sternocleidomastoid muscle and towards the parotid gland.
  • Damage to this nerve can lead to loss of sensation in its distribution area, which would affect the patient while shaving.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Auriculotemporal nerve. This nerve is a branch of the mandibular nerve (V3) of the trigeminal nerve and provides sensory innervation to the anterior portion of the external ear and temporal region. While it is in close proximity to the parotid gland, its primary sensory distribution does not typically include the area affected in this patient's complaint.

 

Option C. Mandibular nerve. The mandibular nerve is the third division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3) and provides sensory innervation to the lower lip, lower teeth, chin, and part of the cheek, as well as motor innervation to the muscles of mastication. Injury to this nerve would more likely result in altered sensation in these areas and possible chewing difficulties, which are not reported by the patient.

 

Option D. Facial nerve. The facial nerve (CN VII) primarily provides motor innervation to the facial muscles. While it does traverse the parotid gland, damage to this nerve would manifest as facial muscle weakness or paralysis (Bell's palsy), not sensory loss in the skin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The question aims to test the understanding of the anatomical relationships and potential complications following parotidectomy, focusing on nerve injury and its clinical manifestations.
  • Identifying the greater auricular nerve as the most likely affected structure in the scenario of sensory loss post-parotidectomy highlights the importance of nerve anatomy and surgical implications in head and neck procedures.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a 3-day history of watery diarrhea and mild abdominal cramps. She denies experiencing any fever, vomiting, or recent travel. The patient also reports that there has been no blood or mucus in her stool, and her appetite has remained relatively unchanged. She mentions that her diet has not varied recently and includes no undercooked foods or unpasteurized dairy products. Laboratory tests, including stool cultures, are performed, and the results are negative for Shiga toxin-producing E. coli (STEC). Given the clinical presentation and laboratory findings, which pathogen is the most likely cause of her diarrhea?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC)

 

  • Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC) is a common cause of traveler's diarrhea and can also affect individuals who have not travelled recently.
  • ETEC causes watery diarrhea by producing enterotoxins that stimulate the lining of the intestines, leading to fluid secretion and diarrhea.
  • The absence of blood or mucus in the stool, along with the negative test for Shiga toxin-producing E. coli, makes ETEC a likely cause of the patient's symptoms, especially in the absence of a travel history, as ETEC can be acquired through contaminated food or water in various settings.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC). EHEC infection is typically associated with bloody diarrhea due to the production of Shiga toxins, which cause damage to the intestinal wall. The absence of blood in the stool and a negative test for Shiga toxin-producing E. coli make EHEC a less likely cause.

 

Option C. Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC). EPEC can cause watery diarrhea, particularly in infants, by adhering to the intestinal epithelium and disrupting its function. However, in the absence of specific epidemiological factors, ETEC is a more common cause of acute watery diarrhea in adults.

 

Option D. Enteroaggregative E. coli (EAEC). EAEC is associated with persistent diarrhea in children and adults in developing countries, characterized by an aggregative adherence pattern on epithelial cells. While it could cause symptoms similar to those described, ETEC remains the more likely cause given the acute presentation and the pattern of symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A research team studying vector-borne diseases is examining the epidemiology of various illnesses in a tropical region. They come across the vector depicted in the photograph provided. This vector is notorious for transmitting several diseases, which have a significant impact on public health. One of the researchers wants to confirm which of the following diseases is NOT typically transmitted by this vector. Considering the vector's species and the endemic diseases it can transmit, which disease should be excluded from the list?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Babesiosis

 

Explanation: Babesiosis is caused by the Babesia parasite, which is typically transmitted through the bite of infected Ixodes ticks, not by the vector depicted in the photograph, which is a sandfly. Sandflies are known to transmit diseases such as Leishmaniasis (Kala azar) and Carrion's disease, but not Babesiosis.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option (a) Kala azar: This is another name for visceral leishmaniasis, which is indeed transmitted by the bite of infected female phlebotomine sandflies.
  • Option (b) Chandipura encephalitis: Chandipura virus is an emerging pathogen associated with encephalitis and is known to be transmitted by sandflies.
  • Option (d) Carrion’s disease: Also known as Bartonellosis, this disease is transmitted by sandflies and can cause a range of symptoms, from skin lesions to severe systemic illness.

 

Educational Objective

 

Sandfly vector can transmit Kala azar, Oriental sore, Sandfly fever. Oraya fever, Chandipura virus, Carrion’s disease, Changuinola virus, summer meningitis, Vesicular stomatitis, Naples virus, Toscana virus, Sicilian virus, Cyprus virus, Turkey virus, Puntotora virus, Vesiculo virus

choices.text: It is a cohort study nested within a case-control study.
It maintains a temporal association between the exposure and the outcome.
It is useful for studying rare diseases with expensive diagnostic tests.
Recall bias is not seen in this type of study.

questions.text: In a recent meeting, a group of epidemiologists discussed the intricacies of various research designs, focusing on the nested case-control study. They highlighted the unique aspects of this design, especially in the context of studying rare diseases. The conversation turned to common misconceptions and specific characteristics that distinguish nested case-control studies from other epidemiological study designs. Which of the following statements is false about nested case-control studies?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is a cohort study nested within a case-control study.

 

Explanation:

 

The statement that a nested case-control study is a cohort study nested within a case-control study is false. In reality, a nested case-control study is a type of case-control study that is conducted within the framework of an existing cohort study. This design involves identifying cases (individuals who develop the outcome of interest) from within the cohort and selecting controls (individuals who do not develop the outcome) from the same cohort.

 

The key feature is that both cases and controls are drawn from participants who were at risk at the beginning of the cohort study, ensuring that exposure data were collected before the outcome occurred.

 

Other Options:

 

Option (b) Maintaining a temporal association: This is true for nested case-control studies, as they are conducted within a cohort that has been followed over time, allowing for the establishment of a timeline where exposures precede the development of outcomes.

 

Option (c) Useful for rare diseases with expensive diagnostic tests: This is also true, as nested case-control studies allow researchers to only perform expensive diagnostic tests on a small subset of the cohort (the cases and selected controls), making it cost-effective for studying rare diseases.

 

Option (d) Recall bias is not seen: This is generally true because the data on exposure in nested case-control studies are usually collected before the outcome has occurred, thus minimizing the potential for recall bias, which is more common in traditional case-control studies where participants may need to recall past exposures after the outcome has developed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NESTED CASE CONTROL STUDY:

 

  • Is a hybrid design where a case control study is nested in a cohort study.
  • Is predominantly a type of Cohort study (due to forward direction).
  • Usefulness limited for studies involving RARE diseases and whose diagnostic tests are very expensive.

choices.text: Deficiency of branched-chain α-keto acid dehydrogenase complex

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic by his parents due to concerns about his vision and academic performance. His teacher has noticed that he frequently squints and tilts his head while trying to read from the board. An ophthalmologic examination reveals lens dislocation. The boy also appears to have unusually long limbs for his age and has experienced several unexplained bone fractures in the past year. Laboratory tests show elevated levels of homocysteine in the urine. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Deficiency of cystathionine β-synthase

 

Explanation:

 

Homocystinuria is most commonly caused by a deficiency of cystathionine β-synthase, an enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of homocysteine to cystathionine. This deficiency leads to the accumulation of homocysteine in the body, which can cause a variety of symptoms including lens dislocation (ectopia lentis), long limbs and skeletal abnormalities (marfanoid habitus), thromboembolism, and developmental delays. The clinical presentation of this patient, including ophthalmologic and skeletal findings along with elevated homocysteine levels, strongly suggests homocystinuria due to cystathionine β-synthase deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

  • A) Deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase: This enzyme deficiency leads to phenylketonuria (PKU), characterized by intellectual disability, seizures, and a musty body odor, due to the accumulation of phenylalanine. It does not typically present with lens dislocation or elevated homocysteine levels.
  • C) Deficiency of hexosaminidase A: This enzyme deficiency causes Tay-Sachs disease, a genetic disorder that results in the destruction of nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord. The classic presentation includes a cherry-red spot on the macula and neurodegeneration, not lens dislocation or skeletal abnormalities.
  • D) Deficiency of branched-chain α-keto acid dehydrogenase complex: This deficiency leads to Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD), characterized by feeding difficulties, vomiting, dehydration, lethargy, and a characteristic sweet odor of urine and earwax. It does not involve lens dislocation or elevated homocysteine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To recognize the clinical features of homocystinuria, including lens dislocation, marfanoid habitus, thromboembolism, and developmental delays, and to identify cystathionine β-synthase deficiency as the most common underlying cause. Understanding the biochemical basis of this condition is crucial for accurate diagnosis and management, including dietary modifications and vitamin supplementation.

questions.text: Identify the Mallampati class of this patient.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Class II

 

  • The image shows Mallampati class II airway where tonsillar pillars and tip of uvula is not seen.

 

 

  • The Mallampati classification, sometimes referred to as the Mallampati score or Mallampati test, is a system used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation.
  • It correlates the visibility of the base of the uvula, faucial pillars, and the soft palate with the ease of laryngeal visualization and intubation.
  • The primary purpose of the Mallampati classification is to assess the potential difficulty of intubation in patients prior to surgery or in any other situation requiring airway management.
  • A higher Mallampati score generally indicates a more challenging intubation.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Anesthesiologists and surgeons use the Mallampati classification as a component of the preoperative airway assessment.
  • This assessment helps them to be prepared for potential airway challenges during surgery and determine if specialized equipment or techniques might be necessary.

choices.text: Spina bifida occulta
Spinal lipoma
Dermal sinus
Any of the above

questions.text: A newborn presented with a tuft of hair over the lumbosacral region. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Any of the above

 

  • Occult spinal dysraphism is a condition where there is a defect in the fusion of midline embryonic neural, vertebral, and mesenchymal structures, and it can be presented in newborns with a tuft of hair over the lumbosacral region.
  • Typically, patients with occult spinal dysraphism have a cutaneous abnormality overlying the lower spine, such as a small dimple, a tuft of hair, or a subcutaneous lipoma.
  • These abnormalities can be a sign of underlying spinal cord abnormalities, and it's important to evaluate them thoroughly to rule out any serious underlying conditions.
  • Spinal dysraphism includes:

 

 

 

  • The initial investigation is usually ultrasound in the neonate and the best investigation is MRI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The presence of a tuft of hair over the lumbosacral region in a newborn may indicate occult spinal dysraphism, which includes conditions such as spina bifida occulta, spinal lipoma, and dermal sinus, all of which can be signs of underlying spinal abnormalities requiring thorough evaluation, typically starting with ultrasound and definitive imaging with MRI.

choices.text: Dull note on right lower chest
Hyper-resonant note on right lower chest

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a past medical history significant for hypertension and coronary artery disease presents to the emergency department complaining of acute onset shortness of breath and chest pain. The patient describes the chest pain as sharp and worsening with deep breaths. His vital signs on presentation are within normal limits, but he appears to be in respiratory distress. Physical examination reveals muffled heart sounds. An electrocardiogram (ECG) is performed, demonstrating low voltage QRS complexes and electrical alternans. A chest X-ray (CXR) is also obtained. Based on the clinical presentation and initial diagnostic tests, which of the following is the most likely finding on auscultation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pericardial friction rub

 

  • The clinical presentation and ECG findings of low voltage QRS complexes and electrical alternans are highly suggestive of pericardial effusion, possibly leading to cardiac tamponade.
  • The cardiac shadow is enlarged, suggestive of money bag appearance in the provided image and is typically seen in pericardial effusion.
  • In this setting, a pericardial friction rub may be auscultated, which is caused by the rubbing of the pericardial layers against each other.
  • The presence of a pericardial friction rubs, in conjunction with the patient's symptoms and ECG findings, supports the diagnosis of pericardial effusion or acute pericarditis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Dull note on right lower chest. This finding is more indicative of pleural effusion. While pleural effusion may coexist with conditions such as heart failure, the clinical presentation and ECG findings in this case are more suggestive of pericardial involvement.

 

Option C. Ellis S curve. This is not a recognized finding on auscultation. It may refer to a concept or term not relevant to clinical auscultation findings.

 

Option D. Hyper-resonant note on right lower chest. A hyper-resonant percussion note is typically found in cases of pneumothorax, not pericardial effusion. This finding would not correlate with the ECG changes seen in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The key educational objective is to recognize the signs and symptoms of pericardial effusion and its potential progression to cardiac tamponade, including the characteristic ECG findings of low voltage QRS complexes and electrical alternans.
  • The presence of a pericardial friction rub on auscultation can further support this diagnosis. Understanding the clinical presentation and appropriate diagnostic findings is crucial for timely management.

choices.text: The local police department has the authority to order the exhumation of a body for further investigation.
An executive magistrate is empowered to order the exhumation of a body for forensic examination.
A post-mortem examination cannot be conducted on an exhumed body under Indian forensic protocols.
The Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC) 174 specifically deals with the inquiry into an exhumed body.

questions.text: In a recent case that has garnered significant media attention, a forensic expert is called upon to provide testimony regarding the legality of exhumation procedures in India, following allegations of foul play in a suspicious death. The expert is asked to clarify who has the authority to order an exhumation and the subsequent forensic processes involved. Which of the following statements accurately reflects the legal provisions for exhumation in the context of Indian law and forensic medicine?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) An executive magistrate is empowered to order the exhumation of a body for forensic examination

 

  • In India, the authority to order the exhumation of a body for forensic examination or further investigation typically rests with an executive magistrate.
  • This legal provision ensures that the process is conducted with due consideration for legal and ethical standards, especially in cases where new evidence comes to light or there is suspicion surrounding the cause of death.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The local police department has the authority to order the exhumation of a body for further investigation. Incorrect. In India, police do not have the authority to order an exhumation. This power is vested in the magistrate.

 

Option C. A post-mortem examination cannot be conducted on an exhumed body under Indian forensic protocols. Incorrect. Post-mortem can and often is performed on exhumed bodies to ascertain the cause of death, especially in cases where the initial post-mortem was inconclusive or not performed.

 

Option D. The Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC) 174 specifically deals with the inquiry into an exhumed body. Incorrect. Section 174 of the Criminal Procedure Code (CrPC) pertains to police inquests in cases of unnatural deaths, but it does not specifically relate to exhumation or post-mortem of exhumed bodies.

 

Inquest Sections:

 

  • 174 CrPc: Police Inquest done in all Inquests other than those specified in 176 Crpc.
  • 176 CrPc: Magistrate Inquest
  • 176 (1) CrPc:
    •  
    • Death of a woman within 7 years of marriage
    • Exhumation done by Executive Magistrate
  • 176 (1A) CrPc: Custodial Deaths done by Judicial Magistrate

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

EXHUMATION

 

  • lt is the legal digging out of an already buried body from grave
  • It should be done and completed in broad daylight.
  • 6-7 samples of soil preserved
  • Disinfectants /pesticides should not be sprinkled
  • In highly putrefied bodies, viscera, hair nails and long bones preserve for poisoning analysis.
  • Time limit: In India, the there is no time limit for ordering of the exhumation
  • Done Under 176 CrPC (Magistrate inquest)

questions.text: A 44-year-old patient presents with complaints of menorrhagia which has been increasing. She has no other medical problems. 3D USG reveals the findings as shown below. All EXCEPT which of the following are choices for medical treatment in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine system (LNGIUS)

 

  • The image shows a large submucosal fibroid
  • This can be managed medically by
    • NSAIDs
    • Antifibrinolytics
    • Combined OCPS
    • Injectable Progesterones (DMPA)
    • SPRMs (ulipristal, mifepristone)
    • GnRH agonists
    • LNG-IUS (Mirena)
  • However LNG IUS (Mirena) , is contra-indicated when there is significant distortion of the endometrial cavity which is seen in a submucosal fibroid; hence an LNG-IUS should not be given to this woman

 

Educational Objective:

 

LNG IUS is contra-indicated when the uterine cavity is distorted either due to a submucosal fibroid/ large intramural distorting the cavity or when there is a Mullerian anomaly

 

Ref: 208, Williams Gynecology, 3rd edition

choices.text: Broad-spectrum antibiotics
Wait and watch
Subcapsular nephrectomy
DJ stenting

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with history of fever and recurrent urinary tract infections has the following CT abdomen. What is the preferred treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Subcapsular nephrectomy

 

  • The history with the CT scan showing an enlarged right kidney with a ‘bear paw sign’, and multiple, low-density areas suggestive of necrosis – correspond with Xantho-granulomatous pyelonephritis (XGP).
  • Xantho-granulomatous pyelonephritis is a chronic granulomatous process believed to be the result of subacute/chronic infection inciting a chronic but incomplete immune reaction.
  • The kidney is eventually replaced by a mass of reactive tissue.
  • Foamy (lipid-laden) macrophages predominate on biopsy.
  • Presentation: Fever, malaise, weight loss, low-grade fever, hematuria and flank pain
  • Treatment: Surgery – subcapsular nephrectomy

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 28th edition, page no. 1471

questions.text: A 30-year-old female in her third trimester of pregnancy presents to the dermatology clinic with a 2-week history of itchy, tense blisters centralized on her abdomen, especially around the umbilical area. The blisters are on an erythematous base and she denies any prior history of similar lesions. She has no significant medical history and her pregnancy has been uneventful until these skin changes. Examination does not reveal involvement of the mucous membranes. Based on the clinical presentation, the most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pemphigoid gestationis

 

PEMPHIGOID GESTATIONIS / GESTATIONAL PEMPHIGOID / HERPES GESTATIONIS

 

  • This autoimmune blistering disorder occurs during pregnancy, typically in the second or third trimester, and is characterized by pruritic, tense blisters on the abdomen, often starting near the umbilicus.

 

 

  • It is associated with antibodies to BP180 and BP230, similar to bullous pemphigoid but is pregnancy-specific.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bullous pemphigoid. Incorrect because it typically affects older individuals and is not associated with pregnancy.

 

Option B. Dermatitis herpetiformis. Incorrect because this condition presents with grouped vesicles and intense pruritus, often on extensor surfaces, and is associated with celiac disease.

 

Option C. PUPPP (Pruritic Urticarial Papules and Plaques of Pregnancy). Incorrect because PUPPP usually presents with urticarial papules and plaques, starts in the stretch marks of the abdomen, and typically does not involve the formation of blisters.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Identify Pemphigoid gestationis as a pruritic, vesiculobullous disorder of pregnancy presenting with tense blisters around the umbilical area, typically occurring in the second or third trimester, without mucosal involvement.

 

Ref: Rook’s textbook of dermatology, 9th Edition, page no. 115.13; Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition, Page no. 472

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by paramedics after being found unresponsive at home with several empty pill bottles around him, including one labelled as a benzodiazepine. Vital signs reveal mild respiratory depression and bradycardia. The medical team is considering the administration of an antidote to reverse the effects of benzodiazepine toxicity. Which of the following drugs is the most appropriate to use in the management of benzodiazepine toxicity?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Flumazenil

 

  • Flumazenil is a benzodiazepine receptor antagonist and is the drug of choice for the reversal of benzodiazepine toxicity.
  • It competitively inhibits the action of benzodiazepines on the gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) receptor, thereby reversing their sedative, anxiolytic, and muscle relaxant effects.
  • It is particularly useful in cases of benzodiazepine overdose or when benzodiazepines have been used for sedation during medical procedures and rapid awakening is required.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Barbiturate. Barbiturates also act on the GABA receptor but in a different manner than benzodiazepines. Using barbiturates in benzodiazepine toxicity would likely worsen central nervous system depression rather than ameliorate it.

 

Option B. Ethyl alcohol. Ethyl alcohol is not an antidote for benzodiazepine toxicity. Co-ingestion of alcohol and benzodiazepines can exacerbate central nervous system depression, leading to more severe toxicity.

 

Option C. Protamine sulphate. Protamine sulphate is an antidote for heparin overdose and has no role in the management of benzodiazepine toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The question assesses the understanding of the management of benzodiazepine toxicity.
  • Flumazenil is the antidote for benzodiazepine overdose, acting as a competitive antagonist at the benzodiazepine binding site on the GABA receptor.
  • It is important for healthcare providers to recognize the appropriate use of flumazenil, including its indications and potential risks, such as precipitating withdrawal seizures in patients with benzodiazepine dependence.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman with a history of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is seen in the high-risk pregnancy clinic for a routine antenatal visit. She is concerned about the risk of congenital heart block in her fetus, as she has read that SLE can increase this risk. Her current medications include low-dose aspirin and a prenatal vitamin. She has been in clinical remission for the past year. The patient inquires about any additional treatments that might reduce the risk of congenital heart block in her baby. Which of the following medications, if added to her treatment regimen, could significantly reduce the chance of heart block in the fetus?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hydroxychloroquine

 

Explanation:


Hydroxychloroquine is used in the management of SLE and has been shown to reduce the risk of congenital heart block in fetuses born to mothers with SLE, particularly those with anti-SSA/Ro and anti-SSB/La antibodies. Hydroxychloroquine is thought to reduce the inflammatory response and possibly the autoantibody-mediated injury to the fetal conduction system.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Azathioprine is an immunosuppressive medication used in SLE, especially in pregnant patients, due to its relative safety in pregnancy. However, it has not been specifically shown to reduce the risk of congenital heart block in fetuses of mothers with SLE.

 

Option B. Cyclophosphamide is used for severe manifestations of SLE but is generally avoided in pregnancy due to its potential teratogenic effects and does not specifically reduce the risk of congenital heart block.

 

Option D. Voclosporin is a newer medication used in the treatment of lupus nephritis. There is limited data on its use in pregnancy, and it is not specifically indicated for the reduction of congenital heart block in fetuses of mothers with SLE.

 

Educational Objective:


The question aims to assess knowledge about the management of pregnant women with SLE and the specific intervention to reduce the risk of congenital heart block in their fetuses. Hydroxychloroquine's role in decreasing the incidence of this condition highlights the importance of tailored therapies in patients with autoimmune diseases during pregnancy.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of severe itching and a diffuse rash. He reports that these symptoms started a few days after returning from a camping trip in a heavily wooded area where he had multiple exposures to soil and freshwater bodies. During his visit, he mentions walking barefoot near the campsite and swimming in a nearby lake. Given his history and clinical presentation, which of the following parasites is least likely to have entered his body through the skin?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trichinella

 

  • Trichinella is a genus of parasitic roundworms that cause trichinellosis (or trichinosis), which is typically acquired by ingesting undercooked or raw meat, especially pork, that contains Trichinella larvae.
  • It does not infect humans through skin contact or penetration.
  • The initial phase of trichinellosis can involve gastrointestinal symptoms, followed by a more systemic phase characterized by muscle pain, fever, swelling, and potentially more severe complications.
  • The patient's contact with soil and water bodies and the nature of his symptoms make Trichinella the least likely parasite to have caused his condition through skin penetration.
  • Life cycle:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ancylostoma and Option D. Necator. Both Ancylostoma (hookworm) and Necator are genera of hookworms that can penetrate human skin, typically through contact with contaminated soil. This mode of entry is consistent with the patient's history of walking barefoot near the campsite. Once in the body, they can migrate to the lungs, be swallowed, and then reside in the intestines, causing anemia and protein loss.

 

Option B. Strongyloides. Strongyloides stercoralis is a parasitic roundworm that can infect humans through skin contact with contaminated soil. The larvae penetrate the skin, migrate through the body, and eventually reach the intestines, where they can cause a variety of symptoms, including dermatological, pulmonary, and gastrointestinal manifestations.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 56-year-old multiparous woman presented with grade II/III uterine prolapse with cystocele. She complains of passing urine on coughing and sneezing. What is the type of urinary incontinence seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C)  Stress incontinence

 

  • Stress incontinence is a form of urine incontinence that patients with prolapse and cystocele experience when they urinate during coughing and sneezing.
  • When there is an increase in intraabdominal pressure, it is known as stress incontinence (e.g. coughing, sneezing, laughing, Valsalva maneuver).
  • In urodynamic investigations, there is no evidence of detrusor muscle contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A: Overflow incontinence the inability to completely empty the bladder, characterized by uncontrollable, continuous urination.
  • Option B: Urge incontinence is the urgent desire to urinate. It happens because of detrusor instability or overactive detrusor muscles.
  • Option D: Patients with neurogenic dysfunction that results in detrusor hyperreflexia experience neurogenic bladder. It is seen in multiple sclerosis, stroke, Parkinson's disease, and spinal injury. They exhibit urge incontinence or urgency.

 

Educational Objective:


This question assesses the examinee's ability to recognize the clinical presentation of stress urinary incontinence, a common type of urinary incontinence characterized by leakage of urine during activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure, such as coughing, sneezing, or lifting, as seen in patients with pelvic floor weakness and uterine prolapse.

 

Reference: Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 6th edition pg 398,399 , Williams textbook of Gynecology 3rd edition pg514

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida presents to her obstetrician with significant discomfort due to an overdistended abdomen. After thorough evaluation, she is diagnosed with polyhydramnios. Considering the severity of her symptoms and the potential risks associated with excessive amniotic fluid, the obstetrician contemplates initiating treatment with indomethacin to reduce amniotic fluid volume. However, the physician must consider contraindications before prescribing this medication. Which of the following is a contraindication for using indomethacin in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gestational age > 32 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

Indomethacin is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that can reduce amniotic fluid volume by decreasing fetal urine production. However, its use is contraindicated beyond 32 weeks of gestation due to the risk of premature closure of the ductus arteriosus, a vital fetal blood vessel that typically closes after birth. Premature closure can lead to pulmonary hypertension and other serious complications in the fetus.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Polyhydramnios due to anencephaly (B): While anencephaly is a condition associated with polyhydramnios, it is not a direct contraindication for the use of indomethacin. The decision to use indomethacin would be based on a comprehensive assessment of the pregnancy and not solely on the cause of polyhydramnios.
  • Muscular dystrophy in the fetus (C): Muscular dystrophy in the fetus does not directly contraindicate the use of indomethacin. The decision to use this medication would depend on other factors, including gestational age and overall fetal condition.
  • Non-immune hydrops (D): Non-immune hydrops is a condition characterized by severe edema in the fetus but is not a contraindication for the use of indomethacin. Treatment decisions would be based on the underlying cause of the hydrops and the gestational age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective of this question is to identify contraindications for the use of indomethacin in the treatment of polyhydramnios. Indomethacin is contraindicated beyond 32 weeks of gestation due to the risk of premature closure of the ductus arteriosus and subsequent fetal complications. Understanding the safe use of medications during pregnancy, including appropriate timing and contraindications, is crucial for managing pregnancy-related complications while minimizing risks to the fetus.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy with a history of chronic idiopathic urticaria has been poorly responsive to non-sedating antihistamines. His parents are also concerned about his low appetite and failure to gain weight adequately for his age. The pediatrician decides to prescribe a medication that not only addresses the urticaria but may also help stimulate the boy's appetite. Which of the following medications, known as an H1-receptor antagonist, also possesses serotonin receptor antagonistic properties on the appetite center and can stimulate appetite?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cyproheptadine

 

  • Cyproheptadine is an H1-receptor antagonist with additional antiserotonergic properties.
  • It is known to stimulate appetite, making it a useful option in patients who need both antihistaminic treatment and appetite stimulation, such as in cases of chronic urticaria with concomitant poor appetite or in conditions requiring weight gain.
  • The serotonin receptor antagonistic effect on the appetite center leads to increased appetite and potential weight gain.

 

Explanation:


Option A. Hydroxyzine. While hydroxyzine is an H1-receptor antagonist and has sedative properties, it does not have a significant effect on stimulating appetite through serotonin receptor antagonism.

 

Option B. Diphenhydramine. Diphenhydramine is primarily an H1-receptor antagonist used for its antihistaminic and sedative effects. It does not have notable serotonin receptor antagonistic properties that would lead to appetite stimulation.

 

Option C. Cetirizine. Cetirizine is a second-generation, non-sedating H1-receptor antagonist. It lacks significant serotonin receptor antagonistic properties and is not associated with appetite stimulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The question aims to assess the understanding of the pharmacological properties of certain antihistamines, particularly their effects beyond H1-receptor antagonism.
  • Cyproheptadine is unique among antihistamines for its additional serotonin receptor antagonistic properties, which can stimulate appetite and potentially lead to weight gain.
  • This makes it a useful therapeutic option in situations where both antihistaminic effects and appetite stimulation are desired.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus is seen in the clinic for a routine follow-up. She has been managing her diabetes with diet, exercise, and metformin. During the visit, she inquires about how physical activity helps in controlling her blood glucose levels. The physician explains the role of a certain glucose transporter that responds to insulin and physical activity by facilitating glucose uptake into cells, particularly in skeletal muscle and adipose tissue. Which of the following glucose transporters is primarily responsible for this insulin-stimulated glucose uptake?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) GLUT-4

 

Explanation:

 

GLUT-4 is the insulin-regulated glucose transporter found primarily in adipose tissues and striated muscle (skeletal and cardiac muscle). In response to insulin and physical activity, GLUT-4 translocates from intracellular vesicles to the cell surface, increasing glucose uptake into the cell. This process is crucial for maintaining blood glucose homeostasis, especially in individuals with insulin sensitivity or diabetes. The woman's improvement in blood glucose control through exercise can be attributed to the increased activity of GLUT-4, enhancing glucose uptake by her muscle cells during physical activity.

 

Other Options:

 

  • A) GLUT-1: GLUT-1 is widely distributed in many tissues and is responsible for basal glucose uptake to satisfy the basic energy needs of the cell. It is not primarily regulated by insulin.
  • B) GLUT-2: GLUT-2 serves as a bidirectional glucose transporter, primarily in liver and pancreatic beta cells. It plays a critical role in glucose sensing for insulin secretion and hepatic glucose production, but it is not directly involved in insulin-stimulated glucose uptake in muscle and fat cells.
  • C) GLUT-3: GLUT-3 is a high-affinity glucose transporter found predominantly in neurons. It ensures a consistent supply of glucose to the brain and is not regulated by insulin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand the role of GLUT-4 in insulin-stimulated glucose uptake in adipose tissue and skeletal muscle and its significance in the context of exercise and diabetes management. Recognizing the unique function of GLUT-4 among other glucose transporters (GLUT-1, GLUT-2, and GLUT-3) is essential for understanding the cellular mechanisms underlying glucose homeostasis and the therapeutic benefits of physical activity in diabetes control.

choices.text: The diagnosis in this case is undescended testis.
Processus vaginalis forms the tunica vaginalis at its distal end.
Gubernaculum testis forms the fundiform ligament.
Lymphatics of the testis drain into paraaortic lymph nodes.

questions.text: A 90-day-old male infant is brought to the pediatric outpatient department due to parental concern about an empty right scrotum. Upon examination, the left testis is palpable within the scrotum, and a small mass is noted in the right inguinal region. An ultrasound confirms the presence of the right testis within the inguinal canal. Based on these findings, which of the following statements is not true regarding the anatomy and pathology relevant to this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gubernaculum testis forms the fundiform ligament

 

  • The gubernaculum testis does not form the fundiform ligament.
  • The gubernaculum is a fibrous cord that connects the fetal testis to the developing scrotum and guides the descent of the testis.
  • In contrast, the fundiform ligament is derived from the lower part of the external oblique aponeurosis and is not a remnant of the gubernaculum.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The diagnosis in this case is undescended testis. This statement is true. An undescended testis (cryptorchidism) is when one or both of the testes have not descended into the scrotum at birth.

 

Option B. Processus vaginalis forms the tunica vaginalis at its distal end. This is true. The processus vaginalis is an outpouching of the peritoneum that, in normal development, forms the tunica vaginalis around the testis.

 

Option D. Lymphatics of the testis drain into paraaortic nodes. This statement is accurate. The lymphatic drainage of the testes is to the paraaortic lymph nodes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • This question aims to test the examinee's knowledge of the embryological development of the male reproductive system, the anatomical pathways involved in testicular descent, and the associated structures and lymphatic drainage.
  • Understanding the normal and pathological processes of testicular descent is important in pediatric assessment and management of cryptorchidism.

choices.text: Dermal nevus
Compound nevus
Large congenital melanocytic nevus
Becker’s nevus

questions.text: Malignant transformation to Melanoma is commonly seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Large congenital melanocytic nevus

 

  • Large congenital melanocytic nevi, especially those over 20 cm (giant congenital melanocytic nevus), have a higher risk of developing melanoma over the individual's lifetime, particularly if they are larger or have a nodular component.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Dermal nevus. Dermal nevi are typically benign and less likely to transform into melanoma compared to congenital melanocytic nevi.

 

Option B. Compound nevus. Compound nevi have Nevus cells in both the epidermis and dermis. They have a slight risk of malignant transformation, but it is not as high as in large congenital melanocytic nevi.

 

Option D. Becker’s nevus. Becker's nevus is a benign cutaneous hamartoma that is usually not associated with malignant transformation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The large congenital melanocytic nevus presents a higher risk for malignant transformation to melanoma compared to other types of nevi, necessitating regular monitoring for changes suggestive of malignancy.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Volume IV, Chapter 143, Page no. 143.2, 143.16

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician complaining of persistent abdominal pain for the past six months. She describes the pain as constant, dull, and not alleviated by eating, bowel movements, or over-the-counter pain medications. She has undergone extensive testing, including abdominal ultrasound, CT scan, and endoscopy, all of which returned normal results. She appears anxious and frustrated about her symptoms, stating they significantly interfere with her daily activities and work. Despite reassurances and negative test results, she is convinced that she has a serious undiagnosed condition. She has a history of depression and anxiety. Her vital signs are within normal limits, and physical examination reveals no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Somatic symptom disorder

 

  • Somatic Symptom Disorder is characterized by an excessive focus on physical symptoms, such as pain, that causes significant distress and impairment in daily functioning.
  • Patients often have high levels of health-related anxiety and may frequently seek medical care.
  • Despite normal investigative results and reassurances from healthcare professionals, their concern about having a serious illness persists.
  • This patient's persistent abdominal pain without an identifiable physical cause, coupled with her high level of concern and the impact on her daily life, supports the diagnosis of somatic symptom disorder.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A) Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). IBS is a functional gastrointestinal disorder characterized by symptoms like abdominal pain, bloating, and altered bowel habits. Although IBS could explain her symptoms, the diagnosis requires that symptoms are relieved by defecation or associated with a change in stool frequency or form, which is not mentioned in this scenario.

 

Option C) Peptic ulcer disease. Peptic ulcer disease presents with epigastric pain that may improve or worsen with eating. However, the absence of any abnormalities in the extensive testing, including endoscopy, makes this diagnosis unlikely.

 

Option D) Generalized anxiety disorder. While the patient has a history of anxiety, generalized anxiety disorder is characterized by excessive worry about various aspects of life, not focused on health or physical symptoms. The primary concern in this case is the physical symptom itself and the fear of a serious illness, rather than generalized anxiety.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • To diagnose somatic symptom disorder, it is essential to recognize patterns of excessive concern, anxiety, and distress related to physical symptoms that are not explained by medical findings.
  • Understanding the criteria for somatic symptom disorder helps differentiate it from related conditions such as IBS, peptic ulcer disease, and generalized anxiety disorder, facilitating appropriate management and support for affected patients.

choices.text: Six’s maximum and minimum thermometer

questions.text: In environmental science and occupational health, assessing the thermal comfort of individuals involves measuring various parameters, including the mean radiant temperature. This metric is crucial for evaluating heat stress and designing suitable interventions to ensure the well-being of workers and occupants in different settings. Which of the following instruments is used to measure the mean radiant temperature?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Globe thermometer

 

Explanation:

 

The mean radiant temperature, which represents the average temperature of the surfaces surrounding an individual, is measured using a globe thermometer.

 

Globe thermometer: Consists of a black globe housed in a ventilated sphere, which absorbs and emits radiant heat similar to the human body. It provides a measure of the radiant heat exchange between an individual and the surrounding environment, crucial for assessing thermal comfort and heat stress.

 

Other Options

 

Option a. Dry bulb thermometer: Measures air temperature.

 

Option b. Wet bulb thermometer: Measures wet bulb temperature, used in conjunction with dry bulb temperature to calculate relative humidity and determine heat stress indices like the Wet Bulb Globe Temperature (WBGT).

 

Option c. Six’s maximum and minimum thermometer: Used to record the maximum and minimum temperatures over a period but does not directly measure mean radiant temperature.

 

Educational Objective

 

Instruments used in Air temperature:

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with a history of three first-trimester miscarriages. She reports a recent diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) despite having no significant family history of clotting disorders. Further questioning reveals a history of migraines and a transient ischemic attack (TIA) two years ago, which was not further investigated. Laboratory investigations include a complete blood count, coagulation profile, and specific tests for autoimmune disorders. Based on the clinical presentation and history, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome (APS)

 

Explanation:

 

Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome (APS) is an autoimmune disorder characterized by the presence of antiphospholipid antibodies in the blood, leading to an increased risk of thrombotic events, such as DVT and TIA, and pregnancy complications, including recurrent miscarriages. The patient's history of multiple miscarriages, a thrombotic event (DVT), and a neurologic event (TIA) strongly suggest APS. Diagnosis is supported by laboratory findings of antiphospholipid antibodies, which may include lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin antibodies, and beta-2 glycoprotein I antibodies.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) (A): While SLE can be associated with antiphospholipid antibodies and similar clinical manifestations, the diagnosis of APS is more consistent with the patient's specific combination of recurrent miscarriages, a thrombotic event, and a TIA without other systemic symptoms typical of SLE.
  • Factor V Leiden Mutation (C): This genetic condition increases the risk of developing abnormal blood clots, but it does not typically present with recurrent miscarriages or a broad spectrum of symptoms like APS.
  • Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (TTP) (D): TTP is a rare blood disorder characterized by clotting in small blood vessels, leading to low platelet counts, anemia, kidney malfunction, and neurological symptoms. The patient's presentation does not strongly align with the full spectrum of TTP symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective of this question is to recognize the clinical features and diagnostic criteria of Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome (APS), differentiating it from other conditions that present with thrombosis and pregnancy complications. APS should be considered in patients with a history of recurrent miscarriages, thrombotic events, and unexplained neurologic incidents, with diagnosis confirmed through specific antiphospholipid antibody testing.

questions.text: A 24-year-old medical student is studying amino acid metabolism and is particularly interested in the process that allows for the exchange of amino groups between amino acids and keto acids. This process is crucial for the synthesis of non-essential amino acids and the disposal of nitrogen from amino acid degradation. Which of the following enzymes catalyzes the reaction that transfers an amino group from an amino acid to an α-keto acid, resulting in the formation of a new amino acid and a new α-keto acid?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alanine transaminase (ALT)

 

Explanation:

 

Transamination is the process by which an amino group from an amino acid is transferred to an α-keto acid, leading to the formation of a new α-keto acid and a new amino acid. This reaction is catalyzed by transaminases or aminotransferases, with Alanine transaminase (ALT) being a prime example. ALT specifically catalyzes the transfer of an amino group from alanine to α-ketoglutarate, forming pyruvate and glutamate. This process is fundamental in amino acid metabolism, allowing for the synthesis of non-essential amino acids and the removal of excess nitrogen from the body.

 

Other Options:

 

  • A) Glutamate dehydrogenase: This enzyme catalyzes the oxidative deamination of glutamate to α-ketoglutarate and ammonia, which is a different process from transamination.
  • C) Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase: This enzyme initiates the urea cycle by catalyzing the synthesis of carbamoyl phosphate from ammonia and bicarbonate, playing a key role in nitrogen disposal but not directly involved in transamination.
  • D) Phenylalanine hydroxylase: This enzyme converts phenylalanine to tyrosine in the presence of tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4), oxygen, and iron. This reaction is a hydroxylation, not a transamination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand the role of transamination in amino acid metabolism, including the key function of enzymes like Alanine transaminase (ALT) in facilitating the transfer of amino groups between amino acids and α-keto acids. This process is essential for the synthesis of non-essential amino acids and nitrogen metabolism, highlighting its importance in maintaining amino acid and nitrogen balance in the body.

questions.text: Identify the image shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fetal scalp electrode

 

  • This is an image of fetal scalp electrodes.
  • They are used in internal electronic fetal monitoring during labor
  • Intrauterine pressure can also be measured simultaneously by passing a catheter in the uterine cavity
  • Internal monitoring can be done only when the cervix is at least 3-4 cm dilated and the membranes have ruptured.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

  • This is an image of fetal scalp electrodes.
  • They are used in internal electronic fetal monitoring during labor

 

Ref: Page no 567, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition

choices.text: Median sternotomy

questions.text: Mrs. Kumar, a 60-year-old woman, presents with complaints of dysphagia and a sensation of pressure in her lower neck, especially when lying down. A visible neck swelling has gradually increased over the past two years. A subsequent ultrasound reveals an extension of the thyroid tissue posterior to the sternum. The patient is scheduled for surgical consultation regarding the management of this retrosternal goitre. Which surgical approach is most commonly utilized for the removal of a retrosternal goitre that causes compressive symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neck

 

  • The commonest surgical approach to a retrosternal goiter is via the neck.
  • Given the anatomical location of the thyroid gland and its extensions, the neck provides the most direct and least invasive access to the gland for surgical removal, even when the goiter extends behind the sternum into the chest.
  • In most cases, the retrosternal portion of the goiter can be delivered into the neck and removed without the need for more invasive thoracic approaches.
  • As it is an extension of goiter from neck, the vascularity also comes from cervical vessels like inferior thyroid artery.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Parasternal. Parasternal thoracotomy is not performed for retrosternal goitres.

 

Option C. Median Sternotomy. Median sternotomy is a surgical approach used when cervical incisions are inadequate or for primary retrosternal goitres.

 

Option D. Intra-oral. This is a minimal invasive approach used for small neck goiters.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The commonest surgical approach to a retrosternal goiter is via the neck.
