choices.text: Predominant enlargement of the distal airspaces
Destruction of respiratory bronchioles with relative sparing of distal airspaces
Thickening of the interlobular septae and honeycombing

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a 40-pack-year smoking history presents to the clinic complaining of progressive shortness of breath over the past few years. He reports a chronic productive cough, especially in the mornings. His physical examination reveals a barrel-shaped chest, diminished breath sounds, and prolonged expiration with an occasional wheeze. Pulmonary function tests show a decreased FEV1/FVC ratio and increased total lung capacity. A high-resolution CT scan of the chest is most likely to show which of the following patterns in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Destruction of respiratory bronchioles with relative sparing of distal airspaces

 

Explanation: Centrilobular emphysema, most commonly associated with smoking, is characterized by the destruction of respiratory bronchioles while relatively sparing the distal alveoli. This pattern leads to airflow obstruction, primarily affecting the upper lobes. The patient's history of smoking and symptoms such as chronic cough, progressive shortness of breath, and changes in chest morphology are indicative of COPD, with centrilobular emphysema being a common pathological finding in such patients.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Predominant enlargement of the distal airspaces: This describes panlobular emphysema, which involves uniform destruction across the entire acinus and is more commonly associated with alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency rather than smoking.
  • Option B. Uniform destruction of the acinus: This also refers to panlobular emphysema, affecting the entire acinus uniformly, which is typically seen in alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, not primarily related to smoking.
  • Option D. Thickening of the interlobular septae and honeycombing: These findings are more indicative of interstitial lung diseases such as idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, which present with a restrictive pattern on pulmonary function tests, not the obstructive pattern seen in emphysema.

 

Educational Objective: The objective of this question is to recognize the clinical and radiographic features of centrilobular emphysema, especially in the context of a patient with a significant smoking history. Understanding the differences between various types of emphysema and other pulmonary pathologies is crucial for accurate diagnosis and appropriate management.

choices.text: Inhibition of RNA dependent DNA Polymerase

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents to the clinic with symptoms of a respiratory tract infection. He has a productive cough, low-grade fever, and mild shortness of breath. His current medications include tiotropium, salbutamol as needed, and a short course of prednisone for COPD exacerbations. Given the presentation and his risk factors, you consider antiviral therapy. You decide to prescribe Oseltamivir. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of Oseltamivir as an antiviral agent?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neuraminidase inhibition

 

  • Oseltamivir exerts its antiviral action by inhibiting the neuraminidase enzyme in influenza viruses.
  • Neuraminidase is critical for viral replication and release from the host cell.
  • By inhibiting this enzyme, Oseltamivir prevents new viral particles from being released, thereby limiting the spread of the virus within the respiratory tract.

 

Explanation:


Option A. Inhibition of M2 receptor. This is not the mechanism of action .of Oseltamivir. The M2 protein is an ion channel in the influenza virus, and its inhibition is the mechanism of action of another class of antivirals, the adamantanes (e.g., amantadine).

 

Option C. Inhibition of RNA-dependent DNA Polymerase. This mechanism is relevant to antiretroviral drugs used in the treatment of HIV, not influenza viruses. Drugs like reverse transcriptase inhibitors work by this mechanism.

 

Option D. Apoptosis of infected cells. While apoptosis can be a cellular response to viral infection, it is not the mechanism by which Oseltamivir exerts its antiviral effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The question assesses the understanding of the mechanism of action of antiviral agents, specifically Oseltamivir.
  • Oseltamivir acts by inhibiting the neuraminidase enzyme of influenza viruses, preventing the release of new viral particles from infected cells and thus limiting the spread of the virus.
  • Understanding the mechanisms of action of antiviral drugs is crucial for their appropriate selection and use in clinical practice.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman has experienced marked pain in her lower extremities on ambulation of more than 300 meters for the past 5 months. On physical examination, her lower extremities are cool and pale, without swelling or erythema. No dorsalis pedis or posterior tibial pulses are palpable. Her body mass index is 32 kg/m2. She is a smoker. Which of the following abnormalities of the vasculature is most likely to account for these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Atherosclerosis

 

  • The clinical presentation described is most consistent with Atherosclerosis.
  • The symptoms of marked pain in the lower extremities on ambulation, which is known as claudication, along with the physical findings of cool, pale extremities and the absence of both dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses, are classic signs of peripheral arterial disease (PAD), most commonly due to atherosclerosis.
  • Atherosclerosis involves the accumulation of plaques within the arterial walls, leading to narrowing and eventually blockage of the arteries.
  • Risk factors for atherosclerosis include a high body mass index (obesity), smoking, and diabetes.
  • In this case, the patient's smoking history and obesity significantly contribute to the likelihood of atherosclerosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lymphatic obstruction. This would more likely present with swelling (lymphedema) of the affected limbs due to the accumulation of lymphatic fluid, not primarily with pain on ambulation or the absence of pulses.

 

Option B. Arteriolosclerosis. This refers to the thickening and hardening of the walls of arterioles, often associated with hypertension and diabetes. It can contribute to the overall process of atherosclerosis but on its own is less likely to cause the significant limb ischemia indicated by the absence of foot pulses and claudication.

 

Option D. Medial calcific sclerosis. Also known as Mönckeberg's sclerosis, it involves calcification of the muscular arteries' tunica media, particularly in older patients. It does not typically lead to significant occlusion of the vessel lumen or the ischemic symptoms seen in atherosclerosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The key educational objective here is to recognize the clinical presentation of peripheral arterial disease (PAD), most often due to atherosclerosis, and to differentiate it from other vascular conditions.
  • Atherosclerosis is characterized by the formation of plaques within the arterial walls, leading to narrowing and obstruction, which can result in ischemic symptoms such as claudication, as well as cool and pale extremities due to reduced blood flow.
  • The absence of palpable pulses in the lower extremities further supports the diagnosis of significant arterial obstruction.
  • Understanding the risk factors for atherosclerosis, such as smoking and obesity, is crucial for identifying individuals at risk and implementing preventive measures.

choices.text: Steroid Response Elements

questions.text: In the investigation of a patient with a suspected endocrine disorder, the role of steroid receptors becomes paramount. When examining the molecular mechanisms involved in steroid hormone action, which of the following components would steroid receptors NOT typically bind to?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Transcription Repressors

 

TRANSCRIPTION REPRESSORS

  • Steroid receptors generally do not bind to transcription repressors.
  • Instead, they usually facilitate gene transcription activation or modulation.
  • Steroid hormones act as Transcription Repressors inside the cell.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Transcription Mediators: Steroid receptors typically interact with transcription mediators, facilitating the initiation or enhancement of gene transcription in response to steroid hormones.

 

Option B. Transcription Promoters: Steroid receptors commonly bind to transcription promoters, regulating the initiation of gene transcription upon hormone binding.

 

Option D. Steroid Response Elements: Steroid receptors commonly bind to specific DNA sequences called steroid response elements (SREs), regulating the transcription of target genes upon hormone binding.

 

  • Mechanism of action of different hormones:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The role of steroid receptors primarily involves binding to transcription mediators, promoters, and steroid response elements to regulate gene expression.
  • Steroid receptors typically do not bind to transcription repressors in the molecular mechanisms of steroid hormone action.

 

Ref: Guyton and Hall, Textbook of Medical Physiology, 13th Edition, Page No. 933

choices.text: Check a prolactin level and if it is elevated, continue bromocriptine therapy
Obtain magnetic resonance (MR) imaging of the brain and base decisions on these findings

questions.text:
A 33-year-old female with a known 5-mm prolactin-producing pituitary adenoma, which has been well-controlled on bromocriptine 0.5 mg orally daily, presents to her endocrinologist with a newly positive pregnancy test. The patient is concerned about the implications of her pituitary adenoma and current medication on her pregnancy. The endocrinologist considers the next best step in managing her condition during pregnancy, taking into account the safety and well-being of both the mother and the developing fetus.

 

Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Discontinue bromocriptine therapy

 

Explanation:

 

In the case of a prolactin-producing pituitary adenoma that is small and well-controlled with bromocriptine, the standard approach during pregnancy is to discontinue bromocriptine therapy. Pregnancy itself leads to natural hyperprolactinemia, which is necessary for lactation postpartum. Most prolactinomas do not significantly increase in size during pregnancy, especially smaller adenomas (<10 mm). Discontinuing bromocriptine is generally considered safe and reduces any potential risk to the fetus associated with medication exposure. Patients should be monitored clinically for signs of tumor growth, such as headaches or vision changes, and prolactin levels can be checked if symptoms suggest significant tumor growth.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Increase bromocriptine to 1 mg daily (B): Increasing the dose of bromocriptine during pregnancy is not recommended unless there is a clear indication, such as significant tumor growth, which is rare, especially in the case of small adenomas.
  • Check a prolactin level and if it is elevated, continue bromocriptine therapy (C): While monitoring prolactin levels can be part of managing prolactinomas, the decision to continue bromocriptine during pregnancy is not solely based on prolactin levels due to the natural increase in prolactin during pregnancy and the low risk of tumor growth in small adenomas.
  • Obtain magnetic resonance (MR) imaging of the brain and base decisions on these findings (D): Routine MR imaging is not indicated in all pregnant patients with prolactinomas, especially if the adenoma is small and the patient is asymptomatic. Imaging may be considered if there are clinical signs of significant tumor growth or complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective of this question is to understand the management of prolactin-producing pituitary adenomas during pregnancy. For small, well-controlled adenomas, discontinuing bromocriptine therapy is often the best approach, with clinical monitoring for signs of tumor growth. This approach minimizes fetal exposure to medications and acknowledges the low risk of significant adenoma enlargement during pregnancy.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with a significant history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and recent hospitalization requiring mechanical ventilation develops a high fever, increased purulent sputum production, and elevated white blood cell count. Cultures from the respiratory secretions grow Pseudomonas aeruginosa, leading to a diagnosis of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient has been receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics; however, given the isolation of Pseudomonas aeruginosa and its known resistance patterns, the clinical team is considering the addition of a more targeted antimicrobial agent. Which of the following antibiotics would be most appropriate to specifically address Pseudomonas aeruginosa in this context?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ceftazidime

 

  • Ceftazidime is a third-generation cephalosporin with broad-spectrum activity and excellent efficacy against Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
  • It is specifically designed to target and inhibit the bacterial cell wall synthesis of Pseudomonas, making it one of the preferred agents for treating infections caused by this pathogen, particularly in the setting of ventilator-associated pneumonia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cefixime. This is an oral third-generation cephalosporin with limited activity against Pseudomonas aeruginosa. It is more commonly used for uncomplicated urinary tract infections and gonorrhea, not for Pseudomonas infections.

 

Option C. Ceftriaxone. Although ceftriaxone is a broad-spectrum third-generation cephalosporin, it does not have sufficient activity against Pseudomonas aeruginosa and is not recommended for infections known to be caused by this organism.

 

Option D. Colistin. Colistin is a polymyxin antibiotic that can be effective against multidrug-resistant Gram-negative bacteria, including Pseudomonas aeruginosa. However, due to its potential for nephrotoxicity and neurotoxicity, it is usually reserved for multidrug-resistant organisms when other options are not viable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ceftazidime is an appropriate antibiotic for the treatment of Pseudomonas aeruginosa infections.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with a history of congestive heart failure is being evaluated for the optimization of her diuretic therapy. She has been on loop diuretics but with suboptimal response and significant electrolyte disturbances. Her nephrologist is considering adjusting her diuretic regimen to better manage her fluid overload while minimizing the risk of further electrolyte imbalances. Which of the following diuretics does not require its presence in the tubular lumen of the kidney for its pharmacological effects?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Aldosterone antagonists

 

  • Aldosterone antagonists, such as spironolactone, work by inhibiting the action of aldosterone at the distal nephron's mineralocorticoid receptor.
  • This action does not require the drug to be present in the tubular lumen, as it acts intracellularly to prevent sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion.
  • This mechanism is distinct from other diuretics, which generally need to reach the tubular lumen to exert their effects.

 

Explanation:


Option A. Thiazide diuretics. These drugs act on the distal convoluted tubule and require presence in the tubular lumen to inhibit the sodium-chloride symporter, thereby exerting their diuretic effect.

 

Option B. Loop diuretics. Loop diuretics, such as furosemide, must reach the luminal side of the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle to inhibit the sodium-potassium-2 chloride cotransporter, which is crucial for their diuretic action.

 

Option C. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors. These agents inhibit the enzyme carbonic anhydrase in the proximal convoluted tubule, leading to diuresis. They need to be present in the tubular lumen to exert this inhibitory effect on the enzyme.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The question aims to highlight the understanding of the mechanisms of action of different classes of diuretics and their site of action within the renal tubules.
  • Specifically, it underlines that aldosterone antagonists act intracellularly on the mineralocorticoid receptors within the distal nephron cells and do not require presence in the tubular lumen to exert their pharmacological effects, in contrast to most other diuretics which must reach the tubular lumen to be effective.

questions.text: In a clinical research seminar, a statistician presents on survival analysis techniques, focusing on the Kaplan-Meier curve, which is widely used to estimate the survival function from lifetime data. The discussion centers on the importance of confidence intervals in interpreting Kaplan-Meier curves, as they provide a range within which the true survival function is expected to lie with a certain probability. The statistician explains different methods used to construct confidence bands around the Kaplan-Meier estimator, highlighting their theoretical foundations and practical applications in medical research. Which of the following bands is correctly associated with constructing confidence intervals around the Kaplan-Meier survival curve?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hall-Wellner bands

 

Explanation:

 

Hall-Wellner bands are specifically associated with constructing confidence intervals around the Kaplan-Meier survival curve. These bands provide a way to visualize the uncertainty or variability around the estimated survival probabilities over time. The Hall-Wellner confidence bands are based on the central limit theorem and are used to create a shaded area around the Kaplan-Meier curve, indicating the range of values within which the true survival function is likely to lie with a specified level of confidence, typically 95%.

 

Other Options:

 

Option (a) Kolmogorov-Smirnov bands: These are not typically used for constructing confidence intervals around Kaplan-Meier curves. The Kolmogorov-Smirnov test is more commonly associated with comparing two empirical distributions.

 

Option (b) Berk and Jones bands: These bands are not a standard method for constructing confidence intervals around Kaplan-Meier survival curves. Berk and Jones is a name not commonly associated with this specific area of survival analysis.

 

Option (d) Hall and Wood bands: This option seems to be a mix-up. While there is a statistical method known as the Hall-Wellner band for Kaplan-Meier curves, "Hall and Wood bands" is not a recognized term in the context of confidence intervals for Kaplan-Meier curves.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Two methods are available to construct the confidence bands for KM curves

 

  • The first has been proposed by Hall and Wellner (1980) (HW)
  • The second, proposed by Nair (1984) - Equal precision (EP)

choices.text: Devascularisation procedure with splenectomy is called Sugiura Futugawa procedure
Alpha blockers like Prazosin can be used for elective medical management in portal hypertension
Linton’s shunt is used for hypersplenism
TIPSS can be done under local anesthesia

questions.text: Choose the incorrect statement regarding the management of portal hypertension.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alpha blockers like Prazosin can be used for elective medical management in portal hypertension

 

  • Beta blockers like propranolol are used in the pharmacotherapy in the elective management of portal hypertension.
  • They work on the principle of splanchnic vasoconstriction that decompresses their portal venous system.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Devascularisation procedure with splenectomy is called Sugiura Futugawa procedure. The Sugiura procedure for esophageal varices combines splenectomy with oesophagogastric devascularisation, permanently interrupting the intraoesophageal portacaval shunt while preserving perioesophageal varices

 

Option C. Linton’s shunt is used for hypersplenism. Before the spleen is removed, the splenic vein is dissected at the splenic porta so that the maximum length of the vein is available. Next, the left renal vein is isolated so that the surgeon can determine where in its course the splenic vein lies closest to the renal vein. The segment of the splenic vein lying on the posterior aspect of the pancreas is then dissected. Once an optimal length of splenic vein has been obtained, an end-to-side splenorenal anastomosis is performed.

 

Option D. TIPSS can be done under local anesthesia. A TIPSS is inserted via the internal jugular vein, superior vena cava and hepatic vein, where in a guidewire is inserted through the hepatic parenchyma into a branch of the portal vein.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Alpha blockers like prazosin are not used for the elective medical management of portal hypertension; rather, non-selective beta blockers such as propranolol are employed for their splanchnic vasoconstrictive effects.

 

Ref: Bailey, 28th Edition, Page no. 1205-06

choices.text: -1.00 DC X 180 degree
-1.00 DS -1.00 DC X 180 degree

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of blurred vision and difficulty focusing on distant objects. Upon examination, the ophthalmologist diagnoses the patient with simple myopic astigmatism. Which of the following would be prescribed for simple myopic astigmatism?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) -1.00 DC X 180 degree

 

  • The correct prescription for simple myopic astigmatism is -1.00 DC × 180 degrees.
  • Simple myopic astigmatism means that one principal meridian of the eye is in focus on the retina, while the other principal meridian is in front of the retina.
  • There are three components to the prescription of glasses for astigmatism: the power of the spherical component (convex or concave dioptre sphere), the power of the cylinder (convex or concave dioptre cylinder), and the axis (orientation) of the cylinder.

 

For example: -1.00 DC × 180 degree

 

  • This prescription indicates that the individual has simple astigmatism, which means one meridian of the eye is in focus while the other is not.
  • In this case, the unfocused meridian is myopic (nearsighted) and requires correction with a concave cylinder lens.
  • The strength of the cylinder lens is -1.00 diopters (DC).
  • The axis of the cylinder is oriented at 180 degrees, which represents the meridian that is most affected by astigmatism.
  • Types of astigmatism:

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For simple myopic astigmatism, where one meridian is correctly focused on the retina and the other is myopic, a concave cylindrical lens is prescribed with the axis of astigmatism specified, as in -1.00 DC X 180 degrees to correct the meridian that is out of focus.

choices.text: Bassini’s repair
Desarda repair
Mayo’s operation
McEvedy’s repair

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman delivered a healthy male child 5 years back. Since then, she has a swelling in the umbilical region and has been posted for surgery for the same. Which operation will be done for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mayo’s operation  

 

  • The above condition describes an umbilical hernia.
  • Mayo's double breasting operation is done for small (< 2cm defect) umbilical hernia.
  • Other treatments include mesh repair (defects > 2 cm).
  • Indications for surgery in umbilical hernia:
    • Defect containing bowel
    • Symptomatic
    • Complicated

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bassini’s repair and Option B. Desarda repair are surgeries used for inguinal hernias.

 

Option D. McEvedy’s repair is a high approach surgery used for femoral hernias. Incision is taken on lower part of Rectus Abdominal (transversely) and pre-peritoneal plane is entered to access the hernia.

 

Other approaches for femoral hernia include:

 

  • Low approach of Lockwood: incision taken below inguinal ligament directly on hernia
  • Inguinal/mid approach of Lothiessan: incision on inguinal canal

 

Ref: Bailey, 28th edition, page no. 1072-74

questions.text: A 32-year-old male with a history of HIV presents to the clinic complaining of odynophagia and retrosternal chest pain that worsens with swallowing. His CD4+ count is 180 cells/μL. An upper endoscopy is performed, revealing multiple shallow ulcers with a target-like appearance in the esophagus. No significant oral thrush is noted. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Herpes simplex virus esophagitis

 

Explanation: Herpes simplex virus (HSV) esophagitis typically presents with odynophagia and may show shallow, target-type ulcerations on endoscopy. It is more common in immunocompromised patients, such as those with HIV, especially when the CD4+ count is low. The target-type ulcers are a classic finding for HSV esophagitis, distinguishing it from other causes of infectious esophagitis.

 

  • Herpes simplex virus esophagitis with target-type shallow ulcerations

 

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Reflux esophagitis: This condition usually presents with heartburn and regurgitation. Endoscopic findings might include erythema, erosions, or ulcers, but these do not typically have a target-like appearance.
  • Option B. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) esophagitis: In immunocompromised patients, CMV esophagitis can occur but is more likely to present with large linear ulcers rather than the small, target-type ulcers seen in HSV esophagitis.
  • Option D. Candida esophagitis: This would be more likely if the patient had oral thrush. Endoscopic findings usually include white plaques or lesions along the esophagus, which can be scraped off, unlike the target ulcers seen in HSV esophagitis.

 

Educational Objective: The aim of this question is to recognize herpes simplex virus esophagitis as a cause of odynophagia in immunocompromised patients, characterized by target-type shallow ulcerations on endoscopy. Differentiating among the various causes of infectious esophagitis is critical for appropriate management and treatment.

choices.text: Billroth-I reconstruction
Billroth-II reconstruction
Braun anastomosis

questions.text: What is the procedure being shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Billroth-II reconstruction

 

  • This involves the removal of the lower part of the stomach and anastomosis of the remaining gastric stump to the jejunum. This is what is depicted in the image shown and is thus, the correct answer.

 

Let's evaluate the provided options regarding the surgical procedures depicted:

 

Option A. Billroth-I reconstruction. This is a procedure where the distal part of the stomach is removed, and the remaining portion of the stomach is directly connected to the duodenum. This option is not depicted in the image.

 

Option C. Braun anastomosis. A modification of the Billroth-II procedure, where a side-to-side anastomosis between the afferent and efferent loops of the jejunum is performed to reduce bile reflux into the stomach. This is not depicted in the image.

 

Option D. Roux-en-Y gastrojejunostomy. In this procedure, the jejunum is divided, and the distal part is connected to the stomach to form the gastrojejunostomy, with the proximal end connected back to the jejunum further down to form a "Y" shape. This is not depicted in the image.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Billroth-II reconstruction is a surgical technique for gastric resection where the remaining portion of the stomach is anastomosed to the jejunum, usually in a retrocolic fashion, to re-establish gastrointestinal continuity following the removal of part of the stomach.
  • This procedure is indicated for various conditions, including peptic ulcer disease and gastric cancer, and is depicted by the anastomosis of the greater curve of the stomach to the jejunum, bypassing the duodenum.
  • Billroth-I gastrectomy: The lower half of the stomach is removed, and the cut end of the stomach is anastomosed to the first part of the duodenum.

 

 

  • Billroth-II gastrectomy: Following resection, the distal end of the stomach is narrowed by the closure of the lesser curve aspect of the remnant. The greater curve aspect is then anastomosed, usually in a retro-colic fashion, to the jejunum.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the clinic with a complaint of a painful burning sensation during urination and a watery discharge from his urethra. He reports recent unprotected sexual encounters. On examination, he has no genital lesions or rash. A Gram stain of the urethral discharge shows numerous pus cells but no organisms. Additionally, culture on routine laboratory media yields no growth. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chlamydia trachomatis

 

  • Chlamydia trachomatis is a common cause of urethritis, especially in cases where Gram stain shows pus cells but no organisms and culture is negative on routine laboratory media.
  • So, Gonorrhoea is ruled out which is the most common cause of urethritis.
  • C. trachomatis is an obligate intracellular pathogen and cannot be cultured on standard bacterial media.
  • The patient's history of unprotected sexual intercourse with multiple partners also increases the likelihood of a sexually transmitted infection like chlamydia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Hemophilus ducreyi causes chancroid, which typically presents with painful genital ulcers and inguinal lymphadenopathy, not primarily urethritis.

 

Option C. Treponema pallidum. The causative agent of syphilis, typically presents with a painless chancre in primary syphilis, not urethritis.

 

Option D. Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Although a common cause of urethritis, it usually shows gram-negative intracellular diplococci on Gram stain, which was not seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Chlamydia trachomatis is identified as the likely cause of urethritis in a patient with pus cells in the urethra but no organisms on Gram stain, and negative routine culture, due to its nature as an obligate intracellular pathogen.
  • The patient's history of unprotected sexual intercourse with multiple partners supports a diagnosis of a sexually transmitted infection like chlamydia.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the clinic with a 6-month history of progressive weakness in both his arms and legs. He reports difficulty getting up from a seated position and lifting objects overhead. On examination, there is noticeable asymmetry in muscle strength, with more pronounced weakness in the quadriceps and forearm flexors. There are no skin rashes observed. Laboratory tests show elevated serum creatine kinase levels. A muscle biopsy is performed, which shows endomysial infiltration by T cells, rimmed vacuoles, and amyloid deposits. Based on the most common etiologies of myositis in this age group, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Inclusion body myositis

 

Explanation:


Inclusion body myositis (IBM) is the most common form of myositis in individuals over 50 years of age. It is characterized by slowly progressive muscle weakness and atrophy, particularly affecting the quadriceps, wrist, and finger flexors. The presence of rimmed vacuoles and amyloid deposits in the muscle biopsy is distinctive for IBM, differentiating it from other inflammatory myopathies.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Dermatomyositis typically presents with a characteristic skin rash (e.g., heliotrope rash, Gottron's papules) in addition to muscle weakness and would show different histopathological features on muscle biopsy.

 

Option C. Polymyositis is an inflammatory myopathy that predominantly affects proximal muscles symmetrically, and its incidence is less common in this age group compared to IBM. Muscle biopsy would show endomysial infiltration without the vacuoles typical of IBM.

 

Option D. Immune-mediated necrotizing myopathy is characterized by severe muscle weakness and very high creatine kinase levels, with muscle biopsy showing prominent muscle fiber necrosis with minimal inflammatory infiltrates. It is less common than IBM in individuals over 50 years of age.

 

Educational Objective:


The question aims to test the knowledge of the most common cause of myositis in individuals over 50 years of age, which is inclusion body myositis. Recognizing the typical clinical presentation and histopathological findings of IBM is crucial for its differentiation from other forms of myositis, guiding appropriate management and prognosis.

questions.text: A public health official is investigating an outbreak of a parasitic infection in a rural community known for small-scale pig farming. Many of the affected individuals report consuming locally produced pork products. The official is considering several parasites that could be involved in this outbreak, taking into account the life cycles and reservoirs of different organisms. Which of the following parasites most likely uses pigs as a reservoir, contributing to the transmission of the infection in this community?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Taenia solium

 

  • Taenia solium, also known as the pork tapeworm, uses pigs as an intermediate host and humans as the definitive host.
  • Humans acquire a tapeworm infection (taeniasis) by consuming undercooked or raw pork that contains cysticerci (larval form).
  • Pigs become infected by ingesting human feces that contain T. solium eggs, which can occur in areas with poor sanitation and where pigs have access to human feces.
  • This cycle makes T. solium a significant concern in communities with close human-pig interactions and where pork consumption is common.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Taenia saginata. Known as the beef tapeworm, uses cattle as the intermediate host and humans as the definitive host. Infection in humans occurs by consuming undercooked or raw beef containing cysticerci.

 

Option C. Trichinella spiralis. While T. spiralis can infect pigs and humans can acquire the infection by eating undercooked pork, Trichinella is not considered to use pigs as a "reservoir" in the same way as Taenia solium, because the pig is an intermediate host for Trichinella, and the parasite can infect a wide range of carnivorous and omnivorous animals.

 

Option D. Ancylostoma. Refers to hookworms, which are soil-transmitted helminths that infect humans through skin contact with contaminated soil, not through the consumption of pork or through pigs as a reservoir.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 16-month-old male child was admitted in the pediatric ward with a history of loose stools for the past 2 weeks and poor weight gain since birth. On detailed evaluation, the child was diagnosed to have cystic fibrosis. Which of the following channels in the gastrointestinal tract are expected to be affected in this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chloride Channels

 

  • Cystic fibrosis is characterized by a genetic defect affecting the CFTR (Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator) gene, which encodes a protein that functions as a chloride channel.
  • This affects various organs, including the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Sodium channels. While sodium channels are important in fluid and electrolyte balance, cystic fibrosis primarily affects chloride channels, not sodium channels.

 

Option B. Calcium channels are crucial in various cellular processes, but they are not the primary channels affected in cystic fibrosis.

 

Option C. Potassium channels help regulate cellular excitability and fluid balance. However, in cystic fibrosis, the defect is in chloride channels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recognize that cystic fibrosis primarily affects chloride channels due to a defect in the CFTR gene, leading to symptoms like malabsorption and chronic lung disease.

 

Ref: Ganong’s Review of Medical physiology, 25th edition, page no. 466

choices.text: Lateral pterygoid

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic with difficulty in chewing. Upon examination, you note hypertrophy of the muscles in the mastication space. She is able to protrude and retract her tongue normally and without pain. As part of your assessment, you review the anatomy of the muscles involved in mastication. Which of the following muscles is not involved in the process of mastication?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Genioglossus

 

  • The Genioglossus muscle is not a muscle of mastication.
  • It is responsible for the protrusion of the tongue, contributing to the movements necessary for articulation and swallowing.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Masseter. The Masseter muscle is one of the primary muscles of mastication, involved in elevating the mandible to close the mouth.

 

Option B. Temporalis. The Temporalis muscle assists in the elevation and retraction of the mandible, also playing a significant role in mastication.

 

Option D. Lateral pterygoid. The Lateral pterygoid muscle is involved in depressing and protruding the mandible, and it helps to open the jaw, making it a muscle of mastication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Genioglossus muscle is not a muscle of mastication but rather a muscle that facilitates tongue movement, specifically protrusion, which is important for speech and swallowing.

questions.text: A young patient began taking a weight loss medication that works by preventing fat absorption from food. She developed easy bruising and increased menstrual bleeding after a few weeks. Which of the following vitamins deficiency is likely to be responsible for her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin K

 

  • Vitamin A, D, E and K are fat soluble vitamins. Their absorption is hampered when the absorption of fat is prevented by a medication (eg Orlistat , Ezetimibe etc).
  • Vitamin K is required for the Gamma carboxylation of Glutamic acid residues of clotting factors 2 ,7 ,9 and 10 in order to activate them. If Vitamin K is deficient due to fat malabsorption, as in the above case, then there can be bleeding manifestations in the form of easy bruising and increased menstrual bleeding in females. The Prothrombin Time (PT) will be elevated.

 

Other options:

 

  • Option A: Vitamin E deficiency can manifest as hemolytic anemia.
  • Option C: Vitamin B6 deficiency can be seen with drugs like Isoniazid, Penicillamine, Hydralazine , OCP. Patients can have peripheral neuritis, lowered seizure threshold, or convulsions.
  • Option D: Vitamin D deficiency leads to the development of rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults.

 

Educational Objective:


The question aims to assess the examinee's knowledge of the effects of fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies, particularly vitamin K, in the context of fat absorption inhibition by weight loss medications, leading to increased bleeding tendencies.

choices.text: Copper intrauterine device
Combination oral contraceptives (COCs)
Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDS)

questions.text: All EXCEPT which of the following are appropriate medical treatments for adenomyosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Copper intrauterine device

 

Explanation:

 

The copper intrauterine device (IUD) is primarily a contraceptive device that does not contain any hormones. In the context of adenomyosis, which involves the presence of endometrial tissue within the myometrium of the uterus, hormonal treatments are often utilized to manage symptoms such as heavy menstrual bleeding and pain. The copper IUD, lacking hormonal activity, is not typically used for the treatment of adenomyosis as it does not alleviate the symptoms and may potentially exacerbate heavy menstrual bleeding.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Combination oral contraceptives (COCs) (B): COCs can be effective in managing adenomyosis symptoms by regulating menstrual cycles, reducing menstrual flow, and providing pain relief, making them a suitable treatment option.
  • Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) (C): NSAIDs are commonly used for pain management in adenomyosis. They help in reducing menstrual pain and inflammation, which are common symptoms of the condition.
  • Levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine system (LNG-IUS) (D): The LNG-IUS is a hormonal IUD that releases levonorgestrel, a progestin, which helps in thinning the endometrial lining and reducing menstrual blood flow. It is considered an effective treatment for adenomyosis-related symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective of this question is to identify appropriate medical treatments for adenomyosis and understand why the copper IUD is not suitable for this condition. Hormonal therapies like COCs, NSAIDs for pain management, and the LNG-IUS are effective in managing the symptoms of adenomyosis by addressing heavy menstrual bleeding and pain. In contrast, the copper IUD, due to its non-hormonal nature, does not offer symptomatic relief for adenomyosis and may exacerbate symptoms.

choices.text: IgM antibodies against Toxoplasma in the mother
IgM antibodies against Toxoplasma in the fetus
IgG antibodies against Toxoplasma in the mother
IgG antibodies against Toxoplasma in the fetus

questions.text: A 2-week-old neonate presents to the pediatric clinic with signs of congenital infection, including chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracranial calcifications. The mother reports that she was healthy throughout the pregnancy and did not have any significant medical history. She mentions having a cat at home and often handling raw meat during meal preparations. Given the clinical presentation and the potential exposure history, congenital toxoplasmosis is suspected. Which of the following laboratory findings would most reliably confirm the diagnosis in the neonate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IgM antibodies against Toxoplasma in the fetus

 

  • The presence of IgM antibodies against Toxoplasma in the neonate (fetus) is the most reliable indicator of congenital toxoplasmosis.
  • IgM antibodies are not transferred from the mother to the fetus through the placenta, so their presence in a neonate's blood indicates an in utero infection and active immune response by the neonate to the pathogen.
  • This finding is crucial for confirming the diagnosis of congenital toxoplasmosis, as it directly reflects the neonate's infection status rather than passive transfer of antibodies from the mother.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. IgM antibodies against Toxoplasma in the mother. While the presence of IgM antibodies in the mother suggests a recent infection, it does not confirm congenital transmission to the fetus.

 

Option C. IgG antibodies against Toxoplasma in the mother. The presence of IgG antibodies in the mother indicates past exposure to Toxoplasma and could suggest immunity. However, maternal IgG antibodies are transferred across the placenta to the fetus and do not differentiate between maternal and fetal infection.

 

Option D. IgG antibodies against Toxoplasma in the fetus. Since IgG antibodies can be passively transferred from the mother to the fetus, the presence of IgG antibodies in the neonate does not necessarily indicate an active infection in the neonate but could rather reflect maternal antibodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The detection of IgM antibodies against Toxoplasma in a newborn indicates congenital infection, as IgM doesn't cross the placenta, meaning these antibodies must have been produced by the fetus itself.
  • Other indicators, like maternal IgM or IgG, don't confirm fetal infection since IgG can cross the placenta and maternal IgM only shows the mother's exposure.
  • Fetal IgG also doesn't necessarily indicate infection, as these could be antibodies passed from the mother.

choices.text: Tail of parotid
Body of parotid
Submandibular gland
Sublingual gland

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a painless, mobile mass in the region of her right jawline. She first noticed the mass several months ago, and it has been slowly increasing in size. She denies any facial weakness, pain, or systemic symptoms. On examination, a firm, non-tender swelling is palpable in the preauricular area, and there is no overlying skin change or facial nerve dysfunction. An MRI of the head shows a well-circumscribed lesion in the superficial lobe of the right parotid gland. Where is the most common site for the benign tumor identified in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tail of parotid

 

  • The tail of the parotid gland is indeed the most common site for pleomorphic adenomas, which aligns with the clinical findings and imaging results of the patient in the vignette.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Body of parotid. The body of the parotid gland, while it can be a site for various salivary gland tumors, is less commonly affected by pleomorphic adenomas compared to the tail of the parotid.

 

Option C. Submandibular gland. The submandibular gland is the second most common salivary gland to be affected by pleomorphic adenomas, but they occur here less frequently than in the parotid gland.

 

Option D. Sublingual gland. The sublingual gland is the least common site for salivary gland tumors, including pleomorphic adenomas, and when they do occur in this site, they are quite rare.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most common site for a pleomorphic adenoma, the most frequent benign tumor of the salivary glands, is the tail of the parotid gland.
  • Patients typically present in the 30-40 age range with a gradually enlarging, firm parotid swelling.
  • The treatment of choice is surgical excision, such as a superficial parotidectomy.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents to the clinic for her annual check-up. Her DEXA scan shows evidence of osteoporosis with a T-score of -3.0 at the lumbar spine. She is postmenopausal and has no other significant medical history. She is interested in pharmacological treatment options for her osteoporosis. What is the first-line management for postmenopausal osteoporosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bisphosphonates

 

  • Bisphosphonates, such as alendronate and risedronate, are often considered the first-line therapy for postmenopausal osteoporosis.
  • These drugs inhibit bone resorption and have been shown to reduce the risk of fractures in postmenopausal women with osteoporosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Estrogen. While estrogen replacement therapy can be effective for preventing bone loss, it is generally not recommended as first-line treatment for osteoporosis due to potential risks, such as an increased risk of breast cancer, thromboembolic events, and cardiovascular disease.

 

Option C. Raloxifene. Raloxifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that is sometimes used in osteoporosis treatment. It is not usually considered first-line treatment but may be an option for those who cannot tolerate bisphosphonates.

 

Option D. Combined Oral Contraceptives. Combined oral contraceptives are not used for the treatment of postmenopausal osteoporosis. They are generally used in reproductive-age women for contraception and are not suitable for postmenopausal women.

questions.text: A second-year medical student is reviewing embryology for an upcoming exam. While studying the development of the gastrointestinal tract, the student learns about the intrinsic ganglia that play a crucial role in gut motility. The student understands that Auerbach's plexus (myenteric plexus) controls the peristalsis of the gastrointestinal tract, and Meissner's plexus (submucosal plexus) regulates the secretion and local blood flow. Knowing the origin of these structures is essential for understanding certain pathologies that involve the enteric nervous system. From which of the following embryological structures do Auerbach's plexus and Meissner's ganglion cells derive?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neural crest

 

  • Auerbach's plexus and Meissner's ganglion cells are derived from the neural crest cells, which migrate to the gut during embryonic development.
  • These cells differentiate to form the enteric nervous system, which is essential for the regulation of the gastrointestinal motility and secretory functions.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Yolk sac. The yolk sac is a membranous sac attached to an embryo, which provides early nutrition in many vertebrates but does not contribute to the development of Auerbach's or Meissner's plexuses.

 

Option B. Primordial germ cell. Primordial germ cells give rise to gametes and are not involved in the development of the enteric nervous system.

 

Option D. Fetal gastrointestinal tract (GIT). While the fetal GIT is the location where the neural crest cells migrate to form the enteric nervous system, it is not the embryological origin of these cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The educational objective of this question is to reinforce the understanding of the embryological development of the enteric nervous system, specifically the origin of Auerbach's plexus and Meissner's ganglion cells.
  • Knowledge of their derivation from neural crest cells is important for understanding normal gut physiology and the pathogenesis of conditions like Hirschsprung disease, which is characterized by the absence of these ganglion cells in the distal bowel.

choices.text: Mobile surgical units performing on-site surgeries
Private clinics offering discounted surgery rates
NGO organized screening camps followed by surgery at a base hospital

questions.text: A public health researcher is evaluating various strategies for addressing the high prevalence of cataract-related blindness in rural India. The researcher is particularly interested in the cost-effectiveness and outreach potential of different surgical intervention models. Given the logistical and financial constraints in rural settings, which of the following strategies for cataract surgery is considered the most cost-effective and has been widely adopted across the country?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) NGO organized screening camps followed by surgery at a base hospital

 

Explanation: Non-Governmental Organizations (NGOs) play a pivotal role in addressing healthcare gaps in low-resource settings, particularly for conditions like cataracts that lead to preventable blindness. Organizing screening camps in rural and underserved areas, followed by surgeries at a base hospital, combines the advantages of wide-reaching community engagement with the efficacy and safety of a hospital-based surgical setting. This approach is cost-effective due to economies of scale, the ability to pool resources, and the focus on high-volume surgeries which reduce per-case costs.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option (a) Mobile surgical units: While providing on-site services, the operational costs and logistical challenges can limit cost-effectiveness and the number of surgeries performed.
  • Option (b) Private clinics: Discounted rates can help, but private clinics may not be as accessible or affordable for the rural and underserved population.
  • Option (d) Government-sponsored insurance: While potentially beneficial, the implementation and coverage might not be comprehensive enough to ensure access to all affected individuals, and administrative costs can reduce cost-effectiveness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Efficiency: Is the measure of relationship between the results achieved and the effort expended in terms of money, resources, and time

 

  • Efficiency: Output/Input
  • Evaluation of efficiency:
    1. Cost-benefit analysis: Both input as well as output is in monetary terms
    2. Cost-effectiveness analysis: Input is in monetary terms whereas output is in terms of‘no. of lives saved’

choices.text: Thoracoscopy is the preferred diagnostic procedure for confirming mesothelioma.
Thoracentesis may cause the spread of the tumor into the chest wall.
Tobacco use has played a significant role in the development of mesothelioma in this patient.
Calretinin and Wilms tumor antigen-1 (WT1) are two immunohistochemical markers useful in the diagnosis of mesothelioma.

questions.text: A 69-year-old male, with a significant history of smoking and prolonged asbestos exposure from ages 30 to 55, presents with right-sided chest pain, exertional breathlessness, and cough. A chest radiograph reveals a right pleural effusion and nodular pleural thickening. Thoracentesis yields a bloody pleural effusion, and cytology raises suspicion for mesothelioma. Considering the clinical and diagnostic findings, which of the following statements is false regarding the management and diagnosis of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tobacco use has played a significant role in the development of mesothelioma in this patient.

 

Explanation:


While tobacco use is a well-established risk factor for many types of cancer, particularly lung cancer, it is not considered a significant risk factor for mesothelioma. Mesothelioma is strongly associated with asbestos exposure, which is the key risk factor in this patient's history. The link between smoking and mesothelioma is not as direct or significant as it is with other thoracic malignancies.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Thoracoscopy is indeed the preferred diagnostic procedure for mesothelioma as it allows for direct visualization of the pleura and the ability to obtain biopsy samples for histological examination, thereby confirming the diagnosis.

 

Option B. Thoracentesis, while a common diagnostic procedure for pleural effusions, carries a risk of tumor spread along the needle tract, a phenomenon known as seeding, which is a consideration in malignancies like mesothelioma.

 

Option D. Calretinin and WT1 are immunohistochemical markers that are commonly used in the diagnosis of mesothelioma. These markers help distinguish mesothelioma from other types of cancer, particularly adenocarcinomas that can also involve the pleura.

 

Educational Objective:


The question aims to clarify the risk factors associated with mesothelioma, emphasizing that asbestos exposure is the primary risk factor, while tobacco use does not play a significant role in its development. It also highlights the importance of thoracoscopy in the diagnosis of mesothelioma and the utility of specific immunohistochemical markers in its differentiation from other malignancies.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Intraocular foreign body

questions.text: What is the diagnosis according to the given image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pseudoexfoliation syndrome

 

  • Diagnosis based on the given image: Pseudoexfoliation syndrome (PES)
  • PES is an age-related degenerative disorder, commonly seen in women.
  • Characterized by deposition of an amorphous grey dandruff-like material on:
    • Pupillary border
    • Anterior lens surface
    • Posterior surface of iris
    • Zonules
    • Ciliary processes
  • Trabecular blockage by exfoliative material can lead to:
    • Secondary open-angle glaucoma
    • Rarely, angle-closure glaucoma
  • Other ocular symptoms may include:
    • Iris sphincter atrophy
    • Anisocoria
    • Heterochromia
  • Systemic manifestations due to abnormal fibrillary deposition may also be seen.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Intraocular foreign body. Common intraocular foreign bodies include glass particles or metal chips. It can lodge in various sites like the anterior chamber, lens, posterior chamber, and vitreous. This can lead to cataract formation, retinal hemorrhages, and tears. Organic foreign bodies can cause infection. Iron foreign bodies can cause siderosis while copper ones can result in chalcosis. An entry wound can be identified with topical fluorescein. In cases of metallic intraocular foreign bodies, MRI is contraindicated. CT scan can be done instead.

 

Option C. Ocular trauma can be a closed-globe or open-globe injury. Closed-globe injury can vary from simple corneal abrasions to widespread intraocular damage. Open-globe injuries include globe rupture or laceration. A corneal abrasion highlighted with fluorescein staining is shown below.

 

 

Option D. Vossius ring is used to describe a ring-shaped pigment dispersal observed on the anterior surface of the lens due to the deposition of brown amorphous pigment granules. It is close to the miosed pupil in diameter. The force of the blow drives the cornea and iris backward, creating an impression of the iris on the lens.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pseudoexfoliation syndrome is diagnosed by the presence of grey dandruff-like material on the pupillary border and anterior lens surface, often leading to secondary open-angle glaucoma due to trabecular blockage by exfoliative material.

questions.text: Which one of the following drugs inhibits neutrophil recruitment?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Colchicine

 

Colchicine is primarily used to treat gout and familial Mediterranean fever. One of its mechanisms of action is the inhibition of neutrophil migration into inflamed tissues, thereby reducing inflammation. It disrupts the microtubules inside cells, including neutrophils, affecting their mobility and reducing their recruitment to sites of inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Montelukast: Montelukast is a leukotriene receptor antagonist used mainly for asthma and allergic rhinitis. While it can reduce inflammation, its primary action is not on neutrophil recruitment.

 

Option B. Sodium Cromolyn: Sodium cromolyn is a mast cell stabilizer used to treat conditions like asthma and allergic rhinitis. It prevents the release of histamine and other inflammatory mediators from mast cells but doesn't directly inhibit neutrophil recruitment.

 

Option D. Febuxostat: Febuxostat is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor used for the treatment of chronic gout. It reduces uric acid production but doesn't specifically inhibit neutrophil recruitment.

 

Educational Objective:


The question tests the examinee's understanding of the mechanisms of action of various drugs used in the treatment of inflammatory conditions, with a specific focus on colchicine's ability to inhibit neutrophil recruitment.

choices.text: Greater negative effect on the endometrium

questions.text: Compared with clomiphene citrate therapy, gonadotropin therapy has which of the following characteristics?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Higher ovulation rate

 

Explanation:

 

Gonadotropin therapy, which involves the administration of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and sometimes luteinizing hormone (LH), directly stimulates the ovaries to produce multiple follicles, resulting in a higher ovulation rate compared to clomiphene citrate. Clomiphene citrate works by inducing ovulation through an indirect mechanism involving the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis, which can be less effective in some patients, particularly those with resistant ovary syndrome or other underlying conditions affecting ovulation.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Lower multiple pregnancy rate (B): Gonadotropin therapy actually has a higher risk of multiple pregnancies compared to clomiphene citrate due to the increased likelihood of inducing the development of multiple follicles.
  • Lower ovarian hyperstimulation rate (C): Gonadotropin therapy is associated with a higher rate of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS), a potentially serious complication, compared to clomiphene citrate. This is due to the more potent and direct ovarian stimulation with gonadotropins.
  • Greater negative effect on the endometrium (D): Clomiphene citrate is known to have a potential adverse effect on the endometrial lining by decreasing its thickness, which can impair implantation. Gonadotropins, on the other hand, do not have this negative effect on the endometrium and may actually support better endometrial development due to the increased estrogen production from multiple follicles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective of this question is to compare the characteristics of gonadotropin therapy with clomiphene citrate therapy in the context of fertility treatments. Gonadotropin therapy is associated with a higher ovulation rate due to direct ovarian stimulation. However, it also carries a higher risk of multiple pregnancies and ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome, contrasting with clomiphene citrate, which can negatively affect the endometrium but generally has a lower risk of these complications. Understanding these differences is crucial for selecting the most appropriate fertility treatment for individual patients based on their specific clinical situation and reproductive goals.

choices.text: Bowing of the posterior maxillary wall due to Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA) in the pterygopalatine fossa
Bowing of the lateral nasal wall due to filling of the maxillary sinus by Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA)
Bowing of the inferior orbital wall due to filling of the antrum by Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA)
Bowing of the lamina papyracea into the orbit due to filling of the ethmoid sinus by Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA)

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with a history of recurrent, profuse epistaxis and progressive nasal obstruction. Physical examination reveals a red, fleshy mass in the nasal cavity. A computed tomography (CT) scan shows anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus. The patient's mother reports that he has been increasingly complaining about a decrease in hearing over the past few months. What is the characteristic radiological sign demonstrated in this patient, and what is its significance?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bowing of the posterior maxillary wall due to Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA) in the pterygopalatine fossa

 

  • The Holman-Miller sign, also known as the Antral sign, is indicative of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) extending into the pterygopalatine fossa, causing anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus.
  • It is a classic finding in JNA.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Bowing of the lateral nasal wall due to filling of the maxillary sinus by Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA). Bowing of the lateral nasal wall due to filling of the maxillary sinus by JNA would not be referred to as the Holman-Miller sign, and this presentation is less typical for JNA, which generally does not fill the sinus but rather displaces the surrounding structures.

 

Option C. Bowing of the inferior orbital wall due to filling of the antrum by Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA). Bowing of the inferior orbital wall due to filling of the antrum by JNA is not associated with JNA, as this tumor typically does not fill the antrum in such a way to cause this specific bowing.

 

Option D. Bowing of the lamina papyracea into the orbit due to filling of the ethmoid sinus by Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA). Bowing of the lamina papyracea into the orbit due to filling of the ethmoid sinus by JNA is not consistent with the Holman-Miller sign, which is specific to the bowing caused by JNA in the pterygopalatine fossa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Holman-Miller sign indicates the presence of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) extending into the pterygopalatine fossa, causing anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus.

choices.text: Total asphyxia induced by the panic and struggle in water
Cold water shock leading to involuntary laryngeal spasm
Rapid fluid shifts causing blood thickening and clot formation
Hemodilution from absorbed freshwater, leading to an electrolyte imbalance

questions.text: In a gripping episode of a forensic investigation TV series, the protagonist, a seasoned forensic expert, is called to a picturesque but remote lakeside campsite where a tragic incident occurred. A young camper was found unresponsive in the shallow waters near the shore early in the morning. Initial suspicions pointed towards an accidental drowning, but the expert's keen observations suggest there might be more to the story. As the investigation unfolds, the forensic expert explains the critical nuances of freshwater drowning to the investigative team, focusing on the physiological effects that could lead to fatal outcomes. The team is particularly interested in understanding the mechanism behind the sudden cardiac arrest observed in the victim. What is the most likely cause of ventricular fibrillation in this case of freshwater drowning?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hemodilution from absorbed freshwater, leading to an electrolyte imbalance

 

  • In freshwater drowning scenarios, the aspiration and absorption of hypotonic freshwater into the bloodstream can cause hemodilution.
  • This dilution effect can disrupt the electrolyte balance, particularly lowering sodium levels while causing cells to swell and burst, releasing potassium.
  • This sudden rise in potassium levels (hyperkalemia) can lead to ventricular fibrillation, a possible cause of sudden cardiac arrest in drowning victims.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Total asphyxia induced by the panic and struggle in water. While total asphyxia due to panic and struggle can lead to hypoxia and unconsciousness, it doesn't directly cause ventricular fibrillation.

 

Option B. Cold water shock leading to involuntary laryngeal spasm. Cold water shock can indeed cause a laryngeal spasm, known as the "gasp" reflex, but this is more likely to lead to aspiration and hypoxia rather than directly causing ventricular fibrillation.

 

Option C. Rapid fluid shifts causing blood thickening and clot formation. Freshwater drowning typically leads to hemodilution rather than hemoconcentration, making blood thickening and clot formation less likely in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hemodilution resulting in hyperkalemia is a key mechanism leading to ventricular fibrillation in freshwater drowning cases.

choices.text: Posterior limb of the internal capsule

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of numbness on the left side of her body. She reports no weakness, vision changes, or difficulty speaking. Her past medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Physical examination reveals intact motor function but decreased sensation to light touch, pain, and temperature on the left side of her face, arm, and leg. Brain MRI is performed to identify the location of the stroke. Which of the following areas is most likely to be affected in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ventral thalamus

 

Explanation:


Pure sensory stroke is most commonly associated with a lesion in the ventral posterior nucleus of the thalamus, which is a part of the ventral thalamus. The thalamus is a critical relay station for sensory information from the body to the cerebral cortex. A stroke affecting the ventral thalamus can lead to a contralateral loss of sensation without motor deficits, consistent with the clinical presentation of a pure sensory stroke.

 

Other Options:


Option A. The genu of the internal capsule primarily contains fibers connecting the cortex with the brainstem and is more associated with motor function. Lesions here typically result in motor deficits rather than isolated sensory loss.

 

Option B. The posterior limb of the internal capsule contains both ascending sensory fibers and descending motor fibers. Infarcts in this area usually lead to a combination of motor and sensory deficits on the contralateral side of the body, not a pure sensory stroke.

 

Option C. The ventral pons contains descending motor tracts and ascending sensory tracts. An infarct in the ventral pons is likely to cause a variety of motor and sensory deficits, including potential cranial nerve involvement, rather than a pure sensory stroke.

 

Educational Objective:


The question aims to assess the understanding of stroke localization and the correlation between the site of the infarct and the clinical presentation. A pure sensory stroke, characterized by isolated sensory deficits without motor involvement, is most commonly due to an infarct in the ventral thalamus, specifically the ventral posterior nucleus. Recognizing the clinical manifestations of strokes in different brain regions is crucial for accurate diagnosis, treatment planning, and prognostication.

choices.text: Increased circumvallate papillae
Increased foliate papillae
Increased filiform papillae
Increased fungiform papillae

questions.text: On neurological examination, a 32-year-old was found to have heightened sensitivity to taste, especially to the bitter taste and was called as supertaster. Which of the following can be expected in this individual?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased fungiform papillae

 

  • Increased fungiform papillae in the tongue can be expected in this patient.
  • In around 25% of the population, there will be heightened sensitivity to taste, especially to the bitter taste.
  • The individuals with this heightened taste sensitivity are called supertasters.
  • This can be most probably explained because of the presence of increased fungiform papillae on the tongue of these individuals.

 

Ref: Ganong’s Review of Medical physiology, 25th edition, page no. 224

questions.text: A 54-year-old farmer from a rural area presents to the clinic with a 2-month history of progressive weakness, weight loss, and yellowing of the skin. He mentions that his diet mainly consists of homemade grains, which have been stored in a damp area of his barn. On examination, the patient appears jaundiced with a palpably enlarged liver. Laboratory investigations reveal markedly elevated liver enzymes, and an abdominal ultrasound suggests the presence of a liver mass, raising the suspicion for hepatic carcinoma. Given the patient's occupational history and dietary habits, which of the following exposures is most concerning for contributing to his current condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aspergillus flavus

 

  • Aspergillus flavus is a species of fungus that produces aflatoxin, a potent hepatotoxic and carcinogenic substance.
  • Aflatoxins are commonly found in improperly stored grains and nuts, especially in damp conditions, which facilitate the growth of this fungus.
  • Chronic exposure to aflatoxins is a well-established risk factor for the development of hepatocellular carcinoma, even in the absence of underlying liver disease.
  • The patient's consumption of homemade grains stored in a damp environment likely led to exposure to aflatoxins, contributing to his liver pathology and the subsequent development of hepatic carcinoma.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Aspergillus niger. While Aspergillus niger can produce mycotoxins, it is more commonly associated with black mold on fruits and vegetables and is less likely to produce aflatoxins that affect grains and contribute to hepatic carcinogenesis.

 

Option C. Candida. Candida species are opportunistic fungi that can cause infections, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. They are not known to produce hepatotoxic mycotoxins and are not associated with hepatic carcinoma.

 

Option D. Cryptococcus/Nocardia. These are different genera of fungi that can cause pulmonary and systemic infections, especially in immunocompromised patients. They do not produce mycotoxins linked to liver damage or hepatic carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aspergillus flavus as the source of aflatoxin production and recognize the clinical manifestations of aflatoxin exposure, which include hepatotoxicity and an increased risk of liver carcinoma.

questions.text: Identify the size of the given blade used for incision and drainage of a superficial abscess and arteriotomy.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 11

 

  • The blade shown in the image is number 11 blade used for skin incisions (E.g., Incision and Drainage) and Arteriotomy.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The blade shown in the image is number 25 blade used for delicate surgical procedures, cutting gingival tissue and making surgical incisions.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with generalized edema and hypertension. Laboratory tests reveal proteinuria, hematuria, and hypoalbuminemia. A kidney biopsy is performed to determine the underlying pathology. Histopathology shows a 'tram track' appearance. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with this histological finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis

 

  • The 'tram track' appearance on renal biopsy is characteristic of MPGN, which is a pattern of kidney disease that can be seen with several different underlying etiologies.
  • This appearance is due to the duplication of the glomerular basement membrane alongside mesangial cell interposition.
  • MPGN is often associated with persistent activation of the complement system, which can be due to a variety of causes, including autoimmune diseases, chronic infections, and monoclonal gammopathies.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Membranous nephropathy. Characterized by thickening of the glomerular basement membrane due to immune complex deposition, but it does not show the 'tram track' appearance.

 

Option C. IgA nephropathy. Also known as Berger's disease, it is the most common form of glomerulonephritis worldwide and is characterized by the deposition of IgA in the glomerulus, but it lacks the 'tram track' appearance.

 

Option D. Crescentic glomerulonephritis. It is typically an aggressive form of glomerulonephritis characterized by the presence of crescents (formed by proliferation of parietal cells of Bowman's capsule) in the glomeruli, not a 'tram track' appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The educational objective is to recognize the histopathological features of different types of glomerulonephritis.
  • The 'tram track' appearance of the glomerular basement membrane is a key feature of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, which can help in distinguishing it from other types of glomerular diseases.
  • Identifying this pattern is important for the diagnosis and subsequent management of patients with glomerulonephritis.

choices.text: Graded Dose-Response Curve
Quantal Dose-Response Curve
Log Dose-Response Curve

questions.text: A group of pharmacology researchers are studying the effects of a new antihypertensive drug. To understand the variation in drug response among different individuals, they are particularly interested in a type of dose-response curve that represents the proportion of the population that responds to a given dose of the drug. This curve helps in determining the dose at which a specific percentage of the population exhibits a predefined effect (e.g., a 50% reduction in blood pressure). Which of the following dose-response curves are the researchers most likely utilizing to assess the variation in sensitivity to different doses of the antihypertensive drug among different individuals?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Quantal Dose-Response Curve

 

  • Quantal dose-response curves are used to assess the variation in drug response among different individuals within a population.
  • These curves plot the percentage of the population that responds to a given dose of a drug, rather than the degree of response in a single individual or tissue.
  • This type of curve is particularly useful for determining the effective dose (ED50) and the lethal dose (LD50) for a population, and it can provide valuable information about the variability of drug response and the safety margin of a drug.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A) Graded Dose-Response Curve. Graded dose-response curves show the relationship between the dose of a drug and the magnitude of the response in an individual organism or tissue. While these curves are useful for understanding the pharmacodynamics of a drug, they do not directly provide information about the variation in response among different individuals.

 

Option C) Log Dose-Response Curve. A log dose-response curve is a type of graded dose-response curve in which the dose is plotted on a logarithmic scale. This curve is useful for determining the potency and efficacy of a drug in an individual or tissue but does not specifically address variations in sensitivity among different individuals.

 

Option D) Therapeutic Index. The therapeutic index is a measure of a drug's safety margin, calculated as the ratio between the toxic dose and the effective dose for a population. While it provides information about the safety of a drug, it does not directly show the variation in response to different doses among different individuals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • To understand that quantal dose-response curves are used to assess the variation in sensitivity to different doses of a drug among different individuals.
  • These curves provide valuable information about the percentage of a population that responds to a given dose, which is crucial for determining effective and safe dosage regimens.
  • Recognizing the differences between quantal dose-response curves and other types of dose-response relationships is important for interpreting pharmacological data and making clinical decisions.

choices.text: May follow an upper respiratory infection
ESR and white blood cell counts are usually normal
Ultrasound of the joint reveals widening of the joint space
The hip is typically held in adduction and internal rotation

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic by his parents due to a sudden onset of limping and refusal to bear weight on his right leg. The parents report that he had a mild upper respiratory tract infection last week, which resolved without any treatment. On examination, the child appears well, without fever or significant irritability, but he is reluctant to move his right hip. Laboratory tests including ESR and white blood cell counts are within normal limits. An ultrasound of the right hip is performed to further evaluate the cause of his symptoms. Which of the following characteristics is NOT typically associated with transient synovitis (toxic synovitis) of the hip?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The hip is typically held in adduction and internal rotation

 

  • Transient synovitis of the hip, also known as toxic synovitis, is a self-limiting inflammation of the synovium of the hip joint, often occurring after an upper respiratory infection.
  • It is the most common cause of acute hip pain and limping in children.
  • The characteristic clinical presentation includes a child who is otherwise well-appearing, with mild to moderate hip or groin pain, and a preference for keeping the hip in a position of comfort, typically flexion and slight abduction and external rotation, not adduction and internal rotation.
  • This position allows for the maximum joint space within the hip, reducing intracapsular pressure and pain.
  • Thus, the typical holding of the hip in adduction and internal rotation is incorrect and not characteristic of transient synovitis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. May follow an upper respiratory infection. This is a common antecedent in transient synovitis, where the inflammation of the hip joint follows a viral upper respiratory tract infection, suggesting a post-infectious or reactive etiology.
