Option B. ESR and white blood cell counts are usually normal. In transient synovitis, systemic inflammatory markers are typically normal or only slightly elevated, reflecting the self-limited and less severe nature of the condition.

 

Option C. Ultrasound of the joint reveals widening of the joint space. Ultrasound findings in transient synovitis may show an effusion or widening of the joint space due to the accumulation of fluid, consistent with inflammation within the joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Transient synovitis (toxic synovitis) of hip: This condition is typically preceded by a viral infection, presents with hip or groin pain, and is associated with normal systemic inflammatory markers and ultrasound findings of joint effusion.
  • Contrary to the incorrect option, the affected hip is not usually held in adduction and internal rotation but rather in flexion with slight abduction and external rotation for comfort.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old post-menopausal woman presents to the outpatient department with a complaint of post-menopausal bleeding that started recently. She has no significant past medical or surgical history and takes no medications. She denies any recent trauma or use of hormone replacement therapy. An ultrasound scan of the pelvis reveals an endometrial thickness of 7mm. The clinician is considering the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient to determine the cause of the bleeding and to rule out any serious underlying conditions.

 

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endometrial aspiration biopsy

 

Explanation:

 

In post-menopausal women presenting with post-menopausal bleeding, the primary concern is to rule out endometrial cancer or other significant endometrial pathology. An endometrial thickness of 7mm on ultrasound in a post-menopausal woman warrants further evaluation. Endometrial aspiration biopsy is a minimally invasive procedure that allows for the direct sampling of endometrial tissue, which can then be examined histologically for any signs of hyperplasia or malignancy. This test is considered the most appropriate next step for evaluating unexplained post-menopausal bleeding when the endometrial thickness is abnormal.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Measurement of CA 125 levels (A): CA 125 is a tumor marker that can be elevated in ovarian cancer and other gynecological malignancies. While it may be used in the evaluation of a pelvic mass or in the monitoring of known ovarian cancer, it is not the first-line test for evaluating post-menopausal bleeding.
  • Pap smear (C): A Pap smear is used to screen for cervical cancer, not endometrial cancer. While important in the overall gynecological care of women, it would not be the most appropriate next step in the evaluation of post-menopausal bleeding with an abnormal endometrial thickness.
  • Preparation for hysterectomy (D): Hysterectomy is a definitive surgical treatment that may be considered for various gynecological conditions, including endometrial cancer. However, it would be premature to proceed with such an invasive approach without first obtaining a definitive diagnosis through less invasive means, such as an endometrial biopsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective of this question is to understand the appropriate evaluation of post-menopausal bleeding with an abnormal endometrial thickness. Endometrial aspiration biopsy is a key diagnostic tool that allows for the histological examination of endometrial tissue to rule out malignancy or other significant pathology as the cause of bleeding.

choices.text: Identified 5th intercostal space anterior to mid axillary line to place the tube
Inserted tube along the lower border of upper rib
Directed tube posteriorly to prevent injury
Skin and fascia is incised, muscles are dissected to reach the pleura

questions.text: A first year surgery resident, on rotation at a hospital, is tasked with inserting an intercostal drainage tube in a 65-year-old patient with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) who was admitted with a severe exacerbation of their symptoms. The surgery resident has previously performed the procedure under supervision, but this is their first time doing it on their own. Which of the following steps is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Inserted tube along the lower border of upper rib

 

  • This is the incorrect step.
  • An intercostal tube (ICD) is placed along the upper border of the lower rib, in order to prevent damage to the neurovascular bundle.
  • This is crucial because the neurovascular bundle (intercostal vein, artery, and nerve) runs along the lower border of each rib.
  • Inserting along the lower border of the upper rib increases the risk of injuring these structures.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Identified 5th intercostal space anterior to mid axillary line to place the tube.

 

  • The 5th intercostal space anterior to the mid-axillary line is a commonly selected site for the insertion of an intercostal drain (ICD).
  • This is because it is situated in the "triangle of safety," an area bounded by the lateral border of the pectoralis major anteriorly, the latissimus dorsi posteriorly, and the horizontal level of the nipple below.
  • Inserting a tube in this area minimizes the risk of injuring important structures, including the long thoracic nerve and vessels.

 

Option C. Directed tube posteriorly to prevent injury.

 

  • Directing the tube posteriorly, especially initially, helps ensure that it enters the pleural space without injuring the lung.
  • Once inside the pleural cavity, the direction of the tube may be adjusted based on the indication for the ICD (e.g., draining an effusion vs. a pneumothorax).

 

Option D. Skin is incised and muscles are dissected.

 

  • After making a skin incision, a blunt dissection and digital exploration of the track are done to ensure that there are no obstructions or adhesions and to create a pathway for the tube.
  • Digital exploration helps ensure that the tube enters the pleural space safely.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The ICD is inserted above the upper border of the lower rib.

questions.text: During a routine labor and delivery rotation, a 28-year-old primigravida at 39 weeks gestation is admitted to the labor ward. Her prenatal course was unremarkable. Upon admission, her cervix is dilated to 4 cm, and effacement is 80%. The fetus is in a cephalic presentation. Continuous fetal heart rate (FHR) monitoring is initiated. After a few hours, the resident notices a recurrent pattern on the FHR monitor: a rapid descent in FHR beginning at the peak of several contractions and a return to baseline after the contractions end. The resident considers the possible causes of this FHR pattern. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the observed FHR pattern?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fetal head compression

 

Explanation:

 

The described FHR pattern is consistent with early decelerations, which are characterized by a gradual decrease in FHR that begins at the onset of a contraction and returns to baseline as the contraction ends. Early decelerations are typically symmetric and mirror the contraction in timing and shape. They are most commonly attributed to fetal head compression during contractions, leading to a vagal response that temporarily slows the fetal heart rate. This is a normal finding during the active phase of labor as the fetal head descends through the birth canal and does not indicate fetal distress.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Fetal hypoxia (A): Hypoxia typically leads to late decelerations, which begin well after the contraction has started and return to baseline well after the contraction ends. Late decelerations are associated with uteroplacental insufficiency and are concerning for fetal distress.
  • Umbilical cord compression (B): This is most commonly associated with variable decelerations, which are abrupt decreases in FHR that can occur at any time in relation to contractions. Variable decelerations vary in timing, shape, and duration and are a sign of umbilical cord compression.
  • Maternal hypotension (C): Maternal hypotension can lead to a decrease in uteroplacental perfusion, potentially causing late decelerations due to fetal hypoxia, rather than the early decelerations seen with fetal head compression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The question aims to assess the ability to interpret fetal heart rate patterns and understand their clinical implications. The correct interpretation of early decelerations, caused by fetal head compression, is crucial and indicates a normal physiological response during labor. It's important to distinguish early decelerations from variable and late decelerations, which may indicate umbilical cord compression and fetal hypoxia, respectively, and require different clinical responses. Understanding these patterns ensures appropriate monitoring and management of labor to optimize fetal outcomes.

choices.text: Increase the dose of beta blocker

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with a history of chest pain with each episode lasting for 20-30 minutes and partial response with sublingual nitrate. ECG shows left ventricular hypertrophy and flat T-wave. He is a known case of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, hypercholesterolemia and currently on aspirin, atenolol, metformin, and lovastatin. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Injection enoxaparin

 

In the background of significant ASCVD risk factors and clinical presentation of ischemic chest pain with ECG changes, diagnosis of NSTE-ACS should be considered and hence, first line management in anticoagulants.

 

Other options:

 

  • Option A - IV GTN can be used if pain is refractory, however, is not the definitive management.
  • Option C - Clopidogrel prevents thrombus propagation and formation, however, does not cause breakdown of the platelet rich thrombus (white thrombus) that is hallmark in NSTE-ACS.
  • Option D - Beta-blockers are used to reduce the ischemic chest pain in chronic stable angina, and cause LV remodeling with significant mortality benefit in patients with LV dysfunction.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/ACS/Chapter 273

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a recent diagnosis of high-grade non-Hodgkin lymphoma begins chemotherapy treatment. Two days after initiating therapy, he presents to the emergency department with nausea, weakness, and palpitations. His ECG shows peaked T-waves and laboratory tests reveal abnormal electrolyte levels. He is diagnosed with tumor lysis syndrome (TLS), a known complication of chemotherapy in malignancies with high cell turnover. Which of the following laboratory findings is NOT typically associated with TLS in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypercalcemia

 

Explanation:


Tumor lysis syndrome is characterized by a set of metabolic abnormalities that occur due to the rapid release of intracellular contents from lysed tumor cells into the bloodstream. These typically include hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia, and hyperphosphatemia. Hypercalcemia, however, is not a feature of TLS; instead, hypocalcemia may occur secondary to hyperphosphatemia, as phosphate binds to calcium in the serum.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Hyperuricemia results from the breakdown of nucleic acids and is a hallmark of TLS, potentially leading to acute kidney injury if not managed promptly.

 

Option B. Hyperkalemia in TLS is due to the release of intracellular potassium into the bloodstream from lysed tumor cells, which can cause life-threatening cardiac arrhythmias.

 

Option C. Hyperphosphatemia occurs due to the release of phosphate from intracellular sources, which can subsequently lead to secondary hypocalcemia due to calcium-phosphate precipitation.

 

Educational Objective:


The question aims to highlight the metabolic disturbances associated with tumor lysis syndrome, emphasizing that hypercalcemia is not a feature of TLS, contrary to the other listed abnormalities. Understanding the typical laboratory abnormalities in TLS is crucial for its prompt recognition and management to prevent renal failure and cardiac complications.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of asthma and recurrent sinusitis presents to the clinic with complaints of worsening shortness of breath, fatigue, and recent onset of numbness and tingling in her feet. She also reports a history of nasal congestion and runny nose that she has attributed to seasonal allergies for many years. On examination, she has wheezing bilaterally, and her complete blood count reveals eosinophilia. Based on her clinical presentation, she is suspected of having eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA). Among the following options, which is the most common manifestation of EGPA in patients like this?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mononeuritis multiplex

 

Explanation:


Mononeuritis multiplex, characterized by asymmetric motor and sensory deficits due to damage to individual nerve bundles, is a common and often early neurological manifestation of eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA). While EGPA can present with various systemic symptoms, including respiratory and allergic symptoms, mononeuritis multiplex is a distinctive feature that frequently prompts consideration of this diagnosis in the appropriate clinical context.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Coronary vasculitis can occur in EGPA but is not the most common manifestation. It is a serious complication that usually appears later in the disease course.

 

Option C. Allergic rhinitis and asthma are frequent in EGPA patients and often precede vasculitic symptoms. However, among the options given, mononeuritis multiplex is a more characteristic manifestation of the vasculitic phase of EGPA.

 

Option D. Renal disease is less commonly associated with EGPA compared to other ANCA-associated vasculitides like granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's) and microscopic polyangiitis. When present, it is typically less severe than in these other conditions.

 

Educational Objective:


The revised question underscores the significance of recognizing mononeuritis multiplex as a common and often early neurological manifestation of eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA). Identifying this manifestation is crucial for the timely diagnosis and management of EGPA, given its potential for significant morbidity.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of urinary tract infections is seen in the clinic for routine follow-up. Her current medications include a prophylactic antibiotic for recurrent UTIs. Recent laboratory tests reveal an isolated increase in serum creatinine from her baseline, with no other abnormalities. She is asymptomatic, with normal blood pressure and no signs of fluid overload or dehydration. Her glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is estimated to be within normal limits based on her cystatin C levels. Which of the following medications is most likely responsible for the isolated increase in her serum creatinine level without an actual change in GFR?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trimethoprim

 

Explanation:


Trimethoprim, a commonly used antibiotic for the prophylaxis and treatment of urinary tract infections, can increase serum creatinine levels without affecting the glomerular filtration rate (GFR). This effect is due to trimethoprim's inhibition of the tubular secretion of creatinine, leading to higher serum levels without an actual decline in renal function. This pharmacological effect is important to recognize to avoid misinterpretation of renal function tests.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Tacrolimus is a calcineurin inhibitor used in transplant medicine that can cause nephrotoxicity, leading to an actual decrease in GFR and increase in serum creatinine.

 

Option C. Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside used to treat heart failure and atrial fibrillation. While digoxin levels can be affected by renal function, it does not typically cause an isolated increase in serum creatinine without affecting GFR.

 

Option D. Penicillin and its derivatives can cause allergic interstitial nephritis, leading to an actual decline in renal function and increase in serum creatinine. However, they do not typically cause an isolated increase in creatinine without a change in GFR through the mechanism seen with trimethoprim.

 

Educational Objective:


The question aims to highlight the importance of recognizing drugs that can affect serum creatinine levels without influencing glomerular filtration rate (GFR), specifically trimethoprim. Understanding these pharmacological effects is crucial to prevent the misinterpretation of renal function tests and to avoid unnecessary diagnostic or therapeutic interventions for perceived renal impairment.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with fatigue, weight loss, and night sweats that have progressively worsened over the past 3 months. On physical examination, the physician notes splenomegaly. Complete blood count reveals elevated white blood cell count with a left shift. A bone marrow biopsy is performed, which shows an increase in mature and immature granulocytes. Cytogenetic analysis is ordered to further characterize the abnormal cells, and the results reveal the presence of a specific chromosomal abnormality known for its association with a hematologic malignancy. The presence of this chromosomal abnormality is known to influence the prognosis of certain leukemias. Which of the following diseases is most likely associated with a worse prognosis due to the presence of this chromosomal abnormality?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acute lymphoblastic leukemia

 

  • The correct answer is Acute lymphoblastic leukemia.
  • The Philadelphia chromosome, resulting from a translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22 (t(9;22), is a hallmark cytogenetic abnormality found in CML.
  • This translocation leads to the formation of the BCR-ABL fusion gene, which has constitutive tyrosine kinase activity that promotes uncontrolled cell proliferation.
  • The presence of the Philadelphia chromosome is a pathognomonic finding in CML and is associated with its pathogenesis.
  • However, t(9;22) is associated with poor prognosis in Acute lymphoblastic leukemia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Chronic myelogenous (CML). While the Philadelphia chromosome is most characteristically associated with CML, it is associated with good prognosis.

 

Option B. Acute myelogenous leukemia (AML). The Philadelphia chromosome is not commonly associated with AML. AML is characterized by other genetic abnormalities and the presentation typically involves signs and symptoms related to bone marrow failure.

 

Option C. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL). CLL is primarily a disease of B lymphocytes and the Philadelphia chromosome is not a characteristic finding in CLL. CLL typically presents with lymphocytosis and is often diagnosed incidentally on routine blood work.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The question tests the examinee's knowledge of the association between specific chromosomal abnormalities and hematologic malignancies.
  • The correct identification of the Philadelphia chromosome with chronic myelogenous leukemia underscores the importance of understanding cytogenetic findings in the diagnosis and prognosis of leukemias.
  • Recognizing the clinical presentation and laboratory findings characteristic of CML, along with the pathognomonic presence of the Philadelphia chromosome, is crucial for accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment planning.
  • The discussion of other options reinforces the differentiation between various types of leukemia and the significance of genetic abnormalities in their classification and prognosis.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female with a history of recurrent urinary tract infections presents to the gastroenterology clinic with a 3-week history of jaundice, pruritus, and dark urine. She denies any use of alcohol or illicit drugs. Her medical history is significant for multiple antibiotic courses for her urinary tract infections. Physical examination reveals jaundice and scratch marks on her skin. Laboratory tests show elevated bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase levels. A liver biopsy indicates a significant reduction in the number of bile ducts within the liver parenchyma. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for her current condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Amoxicillin-clavulanate

 

Explanation: Vanishing bile duct syndrome (VBDS) is a rare condition characterized by the progressive loss of intrahepatic bile ducts, leading to cholestasis. Amoxicillin-clavulanate has been associated with cholestatic liver injury, which in rare cases can progress to VBDS. The patient's history of multiple antibiotic courses for urinary tract infections, coupled with her clinical presentation and biopsy findings, points towards a drug-induced etiology, with amoxicillin-clavulanate being a known offender.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Acetaminophen: While acetaminophen overdose is a common cause of acute liver failure, it typically leads to hepatocellular injury rather than the cholestatic pattern seen in VBDS.
  • Option B. Dimethylformamide: This is a solvent used in industrial settings and is not typically associated with VBDS. Occupational exposures might lead to liver injury, but this is less common and not related to the patient's presentation.
  • Option D. Methotrexate: Methotrexate can cause liver fibrosis and cirrhosis with chronic use, primarily through a hepatocellular pattern of injury. It is not commonly associated with the cholestatic injury or bile duct loss characteristic of VBDS.

 

Educational Objective: The aim of this question is to identify amoxicillin-clavulanate as a cause of drug-induced liver injury manifesting as vanishing bile duct syndrome. Recognizing the link between certain drugs and specific liver injury patterns is crucial for diagnosis, management, and prevention of further liver damage in affected patients.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for a consultation the morning after she had unprotected intercourse. She is extremely anxious and seeks advice on emergency contraceptive options. She reports a history of mild estrogen-related migraines and is currently not on any form of contraception. She expresses a strong preference for a method that would not only serve as an emergency contraceptive but could also be continued for long-term contraception. Considering her medical history and preferences, which of the following would be the most appropriate recommendation for emergency contraception?

 

  1. Levonorgestrel emergency contraceptive pill
  2. Copper Intrauterine Device (IUD)
  3. Ulipristal acetate emergency contraceptive pill
  4. High-dose combined oral contraceptives (COCs) following the Yuzpe regimen
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 only

 

Explanation:

 

Copper Intrauterine Device (IUD): Given the patient's desire for a method that can also provide long-term contraception and her history of estrogen-related migraines (which could contraindicate methods involving estrogen, like the Yuzpe regimen), the copper IUD is the most suitable choice. It is highly effective as an emergency contraceptive when inserted up to 5 days after unprotected intercourse and can provide long-term contraception for up to 10 years.

 

Levonorgestrel Emergency Contraceptive Pill

 

  • Mechanism: Delays ovulation and may alter cervical mucus.
  • Efficacy: Best within 72 hours, effective up to 120 hours.
  • Usage: Over-the-counter, single or two doses.
  • Safety: Well-tolerated, few contraindications.

 

Ulipristal Acetate Emergency Contraceptive Pill

 

  • Mechanism: Inhibits or delays ovulation, effective close to ovulation.
  • Efficacy: Use within 120 hours, more effective than levonorgestrel on day 3.
  • Usage: Prescription needed, single dose.
  • Safety: Not for pregnant or breastfeeding women.

 

High-Dose Combined Oral Contraceptives (Yuzpe Regimen)

 

  • Mechanism: Higher doses of COCs inhibit ovulation.
  • Efficacy: Less effective than other methods, within 72 hours.
  • Usage: COCs - two doses 12 hours apart.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IUDs as Emergency Contraceptives - can be used as emergency contraception to prevent pregnancy ‘up to 5 days after unprotected sexual intercourse. It is ‘more than 99% effective’ (more effective than emergency contraceptive pills)

choices.text: Dorsalis pedis artery lies beneath the deep fascia along the lateral border of dorsum of foot
Close to its termination, it is crossed by the tendon of extensor hallucis longus
It gives rise to the first dorsal metatarsal artery before termination
It lies medial to tendon of extensor hallucis longus

questions.text: A 60-year-old male, known hypertensive, diabetic and a smoker for the past 30 years, visited the surgery OPD with ulcer of the dorsum of foot close to great toe. The unit chief asked one of the first clinical students to look for dorsalis pedis artery pulsation in this patient. Which of the following statements pertaining to this case is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It gives rise to the first dorsal metatarsal artery before termination

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Dorsalis pedis artery lies beneath the deep fascia along the lateral border of dorsum of foot. Dorsalis pedis is a continuation of the anterior tibial artery. It lies beneath the skin fascia along the medial border of the dorsum of foot.

 

Option B. Close to its termination, it is crossed by the tendon of extensor hallucis brevis.

 

Option D. It lies lateral to the tendon of extensor hallucis longus. Dorsalis pedis artery pulsation is used for evaluation of peripheral vascular disease. It is palpated with feet slightly dorsiflexed. It is subcutaneous and passes along a line from the extensor retinaculum to a point just lateral to the EHL tendon. Diminished pulse – vascular insufficiency – arterial disease.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy Abdomen and lower limb, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, Volume II, page no. 383

choices.text: GI tract
Ear drum

questions.text: A team of emergency responders has been called to the scene of a bomb blast in a crowded city center. Upon arrival, they find multiple casualties with various injuries, including blast injuries. In a blast injury, which of the following organs is least vulnerable to the blast wave?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Liver

 

  • The liver, being a solid and dense organ, is least vulnerable to the direct effects of a blast wave.
  • However, this does not mean it's immune to blast injuries altogether.
  • Secondary or tertiary mechanisms, like being struck by flying debris or crushed against another object, can still cause liver injuries.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. GI tract. The gastrointestinal (GI) tract, particularly the hollow parts like the stomach and intestines, is susceptible to blast injuries due to the presence of air within these structures. Typical injuries include subserosal hemorrhage, cecal and ileal perforation.

 

Option B. Lungs. The lungs are among the most vulnerable organs to a blast injury. Being air-filled and highly delicate, they can sustain significant injury from the sudden pressure wave generated by an explosion. Pulmonary barotrauma can lead to potentially life-threatening conditions like pneumothorax (collapsed lung), hemothorax (blood in the pleural cavity), and pulmonary contusion (bruising of the lung tissue).

 

Option D. Ear drum. The eardrum, or tympanic membrane, is particularly sensitive to sudden pressure changes and the most commonly injured organ. It's a thin membrane separating the external ear from the middle ear. The eardrum can easily rupture from the pressure wave of a blast, making it a common injury in explosion scenarios. A ruptured eardrum can cause hearing loss and pain.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • While all the organs listed can be injured during an explosion, the liver, being a solid organ, is least vulnerable to the primary blast wave compared to the air-filled structures like the lungs and GI tract or the delicate eardrum.

choices.text: Retropharyngeal abscess
Thyroid abscess
Esophageal foreign body

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents to the emergency department with a high fever, difficulty swallowing, and a muffled voice. The child appears distressed and drools. The parent mentions the child has not been able to turn their neck comfortably. On physical examination, you notice tenderness and fullness in the posterior pharyngeal wall. A lateral neck X-ray is performed, shown below. Based on the X-ray findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Retropharyngeal abscess

 

  • A Retropharyngeal abscess typically presents with a widened prevertebral space on a lateral neck X-ray, fever, dysphagia, and neck stiffness.
  • The X-ray shown suggests a widened prevertebral space, consistent with this diagnosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Quinsy, or peritonsillar abscess, generally presents with unilateral sore throat, trismus, and deviation of the uvula. An X-ray is not the diagnostic modality of choice for this condition.

 

Option C. Thyroid abscess. A Thyroid abscess would cause a swelling in the region of the thyroid gland in the neck and might not necessarily show the widened prevertebral space as prominently on an X-ray.

 

Option D. Esophageal foreign body. An Esophageal foreign body typically presents with acute onset of symptoms like drooling, inability to swallow, and possibly respiratory distress, depending on the location. An X-ray may show the foreign body if it is radiopaque.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The presence of a widened prevertebral space on a lateral neck X-ray in a child with fever, dysphagia, and neck stiffness is indicative of a retropharyngeal abscess, which is a medical emergency requiring prompt drainage.

choices.text: Clomiphene citrate

questions.text: Mrs. Patel is a 45-year-old woman who presents with a recently diagnosed, localized estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer. Considering her premenopausal status and hormone receptor-positive disease, her oncologist proposes a multimodal treatment strategy that includes surgical resection, radiation, and adjuvant hormonal therapy. Which of the following medications is most appropriate for the hormonal treatment of Mrs. Patel's breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tamoxifen

 

  • Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that is used for hormone receptor-positive breast cancers in premenopausal women.
  • It is used to treat estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer, which is hormone-dependent.
  • Tamoxifen works by blocking the effects of estrogen in the breast tissue, thus preventing the cancer cells from growing and spreading.
  • Tamoxifen is taken orally, usually once a day for five years.
  • Tamoxifen can have side effects, including hot flashes, mood changes, vaginal dryness, and increased risk of blood clots (DVT).
  • Uses of Tamoxifen:
    • Primary prophylaxis of breast cancer in high-risk women
    • Reducing the risk of carcinoma in the contralateral breast
    • Reducing the risk of recurrence of carcinoma in ipsilateral and contralateral breasts

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Estrogen. Estrogen is not used as a treatment for this type of breast cancer because it would promote cancer cell growth.

 

Option B. Clomiphene citrate. Clomiphene citrate is a medication used to induce ovulation in women with fertility issues. It is not used in the treatment of breast cancer.

 

Option D. Anastrazole. It is an aromatase inhibitor used in POST-MENOPAUSAL ER/PR + breast cancers.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that is used for hormone receptor-positive breast cancers in premenopausal women.

choices.text: Urine examination
Liver biopsy
Blood examination
CSF examination

questions.text: A fetus with intrauterine growth restriction was born prematurely with jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, microcephaly, and diffuse petechiae at birth. A brain CT was done which revealed periventricular calcifications. What is the best method for the diagnosis of the etiological agent?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Urine examination

 

  • Based on the clinical presentation, it appears that congenital cytomegalovirus infection is a likely diagnosis.
  • The most effective method for diagnosing the specific cause of the infection is by examining urine samples.
  • In order to diagnose congenital CMV infection, the best specimens to use for culture are urine and saliva, while the best specimens for PCR testing are saliva and cord blood.
  • Clinical features:
      •  
    • Intrauterine growth retardation (IUGR)
    • Prematurity
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Jaundice
    • Blueberry-muffin-like rash
    • Thrombocytopenia, purpura
    • Microcephaly,
    • Intracranial calcifications
    • Chorioretinitis
    • Sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL)
    • Mild increases in CSF protein.
  • Treatment: Ganciclovir can limit hearing loss and improve the developmental outcome in symptomatically infected infants.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Liver biopsy is the gold standard investigation of choice in Wilson disease.

 

Option C. Blood examination will not give us the diagnostic results.

 

Option D. CSF examination is useful in cases of meningitis or neonatal sepsis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Urine examination is the preferred diagnostic method for identifying congenital cytomegalovirus infection, which typically presents with symptoms such as intrauterine growth restriction, prematurity, hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, microcephaly, diffuse petechiae, and periventricular calcifications.

choices.text: It represents melanocytic hamartoma
It causes no visual disturbance
It is associated with facial angiofibroma
They are diagnostic of a neurocutaneous syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is associated with facial angiofibroma 

 

  • The given image shows discrete nodules over the iris, which are referred to as Lisch nodules, and are commonly seen in patients with neurofibromatosis-1 (NF-1).
  • Lisch nodules can present as slightly elevated pigmented areas to distinct ball-like nodules over the iris.
  • Facial angiofibroma (adenoma sebaceum) is a feature of tuberous sclerosis and not neurofibromatosis.
  • NF-1 is clinically diagnosed when any 2 of the following 7 features are present:

 

 

Note: Lisch nodules are characteristically seen in NF-1; however, it can also be seen in NF-2 sometimes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The presence of Lisch nodules on the iris is diagnostic for Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF-1) and is not associated with facial angiofibroma, which is characteristic of Tuberous Sclerosis Complex, not NF-1.

questions.text: Match the following conjugated proteins:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1-d, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a

 

 

 

Incorrect answers:

 

False: Option (b, c, d): are wrong.

 

REF: Vasudevan 9/e: p 43.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman presents to her gynecologist with a 6-month history of irregular menstrual periods, hot flashes, and night sweats. She reports that her menstrual cycle used to be very regular, but she has only had three periods in the last six months. Her medical history is unremarkable, and she has no family history of early menopause. Physical examination is normal, and her pelvic ultrasound does not reveal any abnormalities. Laboratory tests show an elevated FSH level, low estradiol, and normal TSH. The gynecologist considers the possible diagnosis for her symptoms and laboratory findings.

 

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Premature Ovarian Failure (POF)

 

Explanation:

 

Premature Ovarian Failure (POF), also known as primary ovarian insufficiency, is characterized by the loss of normal ovarian function before the age of 40. It presents with symptoms of estrogen deficiency such as irregular periods or amenorrhea, hot flashes, and night sweats, similar to those experienced during menopause. The diagnosis is supported by elevated FSH levels indicating ovarian failure and low estradiol levels reflecting decreased estrogen production. The patient's age, clinical presentation, and laboratory findings are consistent with POF.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) (A): PCOS typically presents with symptoms of oligomenorrhea or amenorrhea, hirsutism, and obesity. Laboratory findings may include elevated LH, normal FSH, and often elevated androgens. The patient's presentation does not align with PCOS.
  • Hypothyroidism (B): Hypothyroidism can cause menstrual irregularities but is usually associated with symptoms of weight gain, cold intolerance, and fatigue, and would show an elevated TSH level, which is not the case here.
  • Hyperprolactinemia (D): Hyperprolactinemia can lead to amenorrhea and galactorrhea but would be indicated by elevated prolactin levels. This patient's normal TSH and lack of galactorrhea make hyperprolactinemia less likely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective of this question is to recognize the clinical presentation and diagnostic criteria for Premature Ovarian Failure (POF). POF should be considered in young women presenting with menopausal symptoms such as irregular periods, hot flashes, and night sweats, especially when accompanied by laboratory evidence of elevated FSH and low estradiol levels. Understanding the distinction between POF and other conditions causing menstrual irregularities is crucial for accurate diagnosis and management.

choices.text: Samter's triad – Asthma, Nasal polyposis (ethmoidal), Aspirin hypersensitivity
Kartagener syndrome – Recurrent sinusitis, pleural effusion, situs inversus
Young syndrome – Recurrent sinusitis, bronchiectasis, infertility due to azoospermia
Gradenigo’s triad – Retro-orbital pain, diplopia, ear discharge

questions.text: A 25-year-old man with a history of recurrent sinus infections and chronic respiratory issues presents to the clinic for a preoperative evaluation. He has a planned septoplasty to address his nasal obstruction. During the evaluation, you notice that the heart sounds are more prominent on the right side of his chest. Which of the following syndromes does this patient most likely have, and what is an incorrect component of its classic presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kartagener syndrome – Recurrent sinusitis, pleural effusion, situs inversus

 

  • Kartagener syndrome is characterized by recurrent sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and situs inversus.
  • The false component in this option is "pleural effusion," which is not a typical feature of Kartagener syndrome.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Samter's triad – Asthma, Nasal polyposis (ethmoidal), Aspirin hypersensitivity. Samter's triad is correctly described as consisting of asthma, nasal polyposis, and aspirin hypersensitivity. This triad of conditions is commonly seen together and is accurate as stated.

 

Option C. Young syndrome – Recurrent sinusitis, bronchiectasis, infertility due to azoospermia. Young syndrome is accurately described with the triad of recurrent sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and male infertility due to azoospermia. This syndrome is a correct statement.

 

Option D. Gradenigo’s triad – Retro-orbital pain, diplopia, ear discharge. Gradenigo’s triad involves retro-orbital pain, diplopia, and ear discharge, typically due to petrous apicitis complicating otitis media. This triad is correctly stated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Kartagener syndrome is characterized by the triad of recurrent sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and situs inversus, not pleural effusion.

questions.text: Which of the following inhibits the synthesis of glucocorticoid?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Metyrapone

 

Explanation:


Metyrapone is a drug that inhibits the enzyme 11β-hydroxylase, which is crucial for the final step of cortisol synthesis in the adrenal cortex. By inhibiting this enzyme, metyrapone effectively decreases glucocorticoid (cortisol) production. It is used in the diagnostic testing of adrenal insufficiency and in the medical treatment of Cushing's syndrome.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Mifepristone: This is a glucocorticoid receptor antagonist, not an inhibitor of glucocorticoid synthesis. It prevents glucocorticoids from exerting their effects by blocking their receptors.


Option B. Flutamide: This is an androgen receptor antagonist used in the treatment of prostate cancer. It does not inhibit glucocorticoid synthesis.


Option C. Finasteride: This is a 5α-reductase inhibitor, which prevents the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT). It is used primarily in the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia and androgenetic alopecia and does not affect glucocorticoid synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:


The question tests the examinee's understanding of the pharmacological agents affecting steroid synthesis and their mechanisms of action, specifically focusing on metyrapone's role in inhibiting glucocorticoid synthesis.

choices.text: Half hitch knot
﻿﻿﻿Reef knot
﻿﻿﻿Surgeon's knot
﻿﻿﻿Crossed half hitch knot

questions.text: Identify the type of knot seen in the image given below.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Surgeon’s Knot

 

  • The image shows a Surgeon’s knot.
  • Other Surgical knots:
    • Reef/Square knot:
      • It is the most Basic Surgical Knot.
      • Two Throws in “Opposite Directions”.

 

 

  • Granny Knot:
    • Two Throws in the Same Direction.
    • Not as Strong as Square Knot – Can Slip

 

 

  • Surgeon’s Knot:
    • Initial Throw is Pulled Through Twice
    • Second Throw in Opposite Direction
    • More Stable than a Square Knot

 

 

  • Surgical Slip Knot (Double Half-Hitch):
    • Keeping Tension on One End the Initial Knot is Thrown Twice in the Same Direction and then Pulled Tight
    • Essentially a “Purposeful” Granny Knot
    • Following Throws in Opposite Directions to Lock
    • Allows Initial Tightening of the Knot to Ensure Tightness

 

Educational objective:

 

TYPES OF SURGICAL KNOTS

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a long history of diabetes mellitus has noted pain in his right leg for the past 3 months. On physical examination, there are no abnormal findings. Laboratory studies show his serum phosphorus is 4.8 mg/dL, calcium is 8.9 mg/dL, urea nitrogen is 48 mg/dL, and creatinine is 5.0 mg/dL. Based upon the appearance of the parathyroid glands removed at surgery and shown here, which of the following complications is he most likely to have?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Osteitis fibrosa cystica

 

  • Based on the laboratory findings of elevated urea nitrogen and creatinine levels, the patient has renal insufficiency, which is common in long-standing diabetes mellitus.
  • The parathyroid glands' appearance in the image could suggest parathyroid hyperplasia, which can be secondary to chronic renal insufficiency.
  • In this context, the most likely complication the patient is at risk of developing is Osteitis fibrosa cystica.
  • This condition is associated with secondary hyperparathyroidism due to chronic kidney disease (CKD), where the parathyroid glands are overactive in response to low calcium and high phosphorus levels, often due to the kidneys' inability to convert vitamin D to its active form and excrete phosphorus.
  • The overactivity of the parathyroid glands leads to excessive bone resorption, which can manifest as bone pain, which the patient is experiencing.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Gout. While gout could cause joint pain and is associated with kidney disease, it does not directly relate to parathyroid gland abnormalities or the patient's specific laboratory values.

 

Option B. Polyneuritis. Diabetes can lead to polyneuropathy, presenting as a symmetric pain or loss of sensation in the extremities. However, this is less likely to be directly associated with the parathyroid gland appearance or the abnormal lab values presented.

 

Option C. Chronic arthritis. Arthritis can cause pain and could be a complication of diabetes or kidney disease, but it is not specifically linked to the parathyroid gland appearance or the laboratory findings indicative of secondary hyperparathyroidism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The educational objective is to recognize the link between chronic kidney disease and secondary hyperparathyroidism, leading to complications such as osteitis fibrosa cystica.
  • The parathyroid gland hyperplasia is a compensatory response to chronic renal insufficiency, which disrupts calcium and phosphorus homeostasis, prompting the parathyroid glands to increase parathyroid hormone (PTH) production.
  • This excessive PTH leads to the characteristic bone changes of osteitis fibrosa cystica, which can manifest as bone pain and is supported by the patient's symptoms and laboratory values.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman at 38 weeks of gestation with a diagnosis of pre-eclampsia is scheduled for an elective cesarean section. She has a blood pressure of 160/110 mmHg, proteinuria, and edema. The obstetric team is discussing the best anesthesia approach that minimizes risk to both mother and fetus. For this patient with pre-eclampsia, which anesthesia method is most appropriate to manage her condition during cesarean delivery?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Epidural anesthesia

 

  • The best type of anesthesia for pre-eclampsia is Epidural anesthesia (Option B).
  • Epidural anesthesia involves the injection of anesthetic agents into the epidural space of the spine.
  • It can be titrated to the desired level of anesthesia/analgesia and can be maintained for longer periods.
  • Key Advantages in the context of pre-eclampsia:
    • Avoidance of airway manipulation: As mentioned, pregnancy can present with airway challenges due to edema, short neck, and increased breast size.
    • Preservation of Airway Reflexes: There's no risk of aspiration, which is a concern in pregnant patients due to delayed gastric emptying.
    • Decreased drug passage to fetus: Fewer systemic drugs are used, which reduces the risk of placental transfer and potential neonatal depression.
    • Pain management: Effective pain control can help in reducing catecholamine levels, which can otherwise increase blood pressure further in pre-eclamptic patients.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Spinal anesthesia. While it provides rapid and effective anesthesia for surgeries below the abdomen, it may cause a significant drop in blood pressure, which can be concerning in patients with pre-eclampsia.

 

Option C. General anesthesia. In pregnant patients, especially with conditions like pre-eclampsia, general anesthesia presents multiple challenges:

 

  • Airway difficulties
  • Risk of aspiration: Pregnant patients are at an increased risk of aspiration during induction and intubation due to delayed gastric emptying.
  • Drug transfer to fetus: Many anesthetic agents can cross the placenta, potentially affecting the fetus.

 

Option D. Caudal block. A caudal block is a type of epidural where the anesthetic is administered at the sacral hiatus. It's typically used in pediatric patients. While it can provide good analgesia, it's not the primary choice for managing pre-eclampsia in obstetric procedures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Epidural anesthesia is the preferred method for cesarean delivery in patients with pre-eclampsia because it provides a controllable and gradual onset of anesthesia, minimizing sudden changes in hemodynamics, and avoiding the increased risks of airway complications and fetal drug exposure associated with general anesthesia.

questions.text:
A junior resident  is preparing a presentation on the transmission dynamics of infectious diseases for a class of 1st year medical students. During the class, the focus is on the concept of carriers and the role they play in the spread of infectious diseases. The student learns about different types of carriers, each defined by the stage of disease at which they can transmit the pathogen to others. Based on the information provided, which of the following diseases is associated with individuals being able to shed the infectious agent during the incubation period, before the onset of overt symptoms?

 

  1. Measles
  2. Typhoid
  3. Poliomyelitis
  4. Cholera
  5. Hepatitis B

 

Select the correct answer using the letter choices below:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 3 and 5

 

Explanation:

 

Incubatory carriers are individuals who shed the infectious agent during the incubation period of a disease, which is the time between the initial infection and the onset of symptoms. This category includes diseases such as:

 

  • Measles: Known for its highly contagious nature, measles can be transmitted by incubatory carriers who are infectious before the characteristic symptoms, like rash, appear.
  • Poliomyelitis (Polio): The poliovirus can be shed in the feces during the incubation period, making transmission possible before the appearance of symptoms such as paralysis.
  • Hepatitis B: This virus can be transmitted during the incubation period, well before the onset of any symptoms related to liver dysfunction.

 

Typhoid and Cholera, while also significant public health concerns, are more commonly associated with convalescent carriers (Typhoid) or healthy carriers (Cholera), who can transmit the disease after symptoms have subsided or even without showing symptoms, respectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carriers by type:

 

  1. Incubatory Carriers: Shed infectious agent during incubation period of disease, e.g. Measles, Mumps, Polio, Pertussis, Influenza, Diphtheria, Hepatitis-B
  2. Convalescent Carriers: shed the disease agent during the period of Convalescence, e.g. Typhoid, Bacillary Dysentery, Amoebic Dysentery, Cholera, Diphtheria & Pertussis (Clinical recovery does not coincide with bacteriological recovery)
  3. Healthy carriers: emerge from subclinical cases without suffering from overt disease, e.g. Poliomyelitis, Cholera, Meningococcal Meningitis, Diphtheria & Salmonellosis

choices.text: Prescribe two tablets of Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) containing 60 mg elemental Iron and 500 mcg Folic Acid each, taken orally once daily, with close monitoring of hemoglobin levels and patient adherence to treatment.
Initiate Intravenous (IV) Iron Sucrose therapy as the primary treatment, considering the moderate severity of anemia and the potential for rapid correction before delivery.

Recommend two IFA tablets daily and consider the addition of IV Iron Sucrose or Ferric Carboxy Maltose (FCM) if there is evidence of non-compliance or insufficient response to oral therapy by the next follow-up visit.
Directly opt for Intramuscular (IM) Ferric Carboxy Maltose (FCM) administration, bypassing oral supplementation, to ensure rapid improvement in hemoglobin levels.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman presents to a tertiary care center at 26 weeks of gestation for a routine antenatal check-up. She has been generally feeling fatigued over the past few weeks with occasional palpitations. Her obstetric history is unremarkable, and she has been adherent to her prenatal vitamins. On examination, she appears pale. Laboratory tests reveal a hemoglobin level of 9.8 g/dl, indicating moderate anemia. The healthcare provider considers the Anemia Mukt Bharat initiative guidelines to formulate an appropriate management plan, taking into account the potential challenges of treatment compliance and the gestational age at which anemia has been diagnosed. Given the patient's clinical presentation and the Anemia Mukt Bharat initiative guidelines, which of the following management strategies is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Recommend two IFA tablets daily and consider the addition of IV Iron Sucrose or Ferric Carboxy Maltose (FCM) if there is evidence of non-compliance or insufficient response to oral therapy by the next follow-up visit.

 

Explanation:

 

For moderate anemia in pregnancy (hemoglobin levels between 7 and 9.9 g/dl), the Anemia Mukt Bharat initiative recommends starting with two tablets of Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) daily, each containing 60 mg elemental iron and 500 mcg folic acid. This approach addresses the immediate need to increase iron stores and improve hemoglobin levels. Given the moderate severity of anemia and the patient's current gestational age, it is prudent to initiate oral therapy while considering the potential need for more aggressive treatment, such as IV Iron Sucrose or Ferric Carboxy Maltose (FCM), if oral therapy proves inadequate or if compliance issues arise. This strategy allows for a tailored approach to anemia management in pregnancy, balancing the benefits of oral supplementation with the rapid correction that parenteral therapy can offer in certain circumstances.

 

Prophylactic Dose and Regime for Iron Folic Acid Supplementation (under AMB)

 

 

Note - *NPNL – Non-Pregnant non-lactating

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treatment guidelines under the Anaemia Mukt Bharat initiative for pregnant women based on their hemoglobin levels:

choices.text: During an Under Immunized Population (UIP) Survey for polio to identify areas with low vaccination coverage and potential polio cases
In a targeted screening program for sexually transmitted diseases (STDs) within high-risk populations or social networks
As part of a campaign to detect leprosy by examining individuals for hypopigmented patches and other signs
While investigating a typhoid outbreak, to test individuals who have been in close contact with confirmed typhoid cases

questions.text: In an effort to enhance public health initiatives, a local health department is evaluating various strategies to optimize the detection and control of infectious diseases within the community. One of the methods under consideration is "cluster testing," which involves testing groups or "clusters" of individuals who are interconnected in some way, such as through geographic proximity, social interactions, or shared exposures. The health department aims to implement this strategy effectively to address specific public health challenges. Given the context, in which of the following scenarios would "cluster testing" be most appropriately applied?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) In a targeted screening program for sexually transmitted diseases (STDs) within high-risk populations or social networks

 

Explanation:

 

Cluster testing is particularly suited to scenarios where individuals within a specific group or network are at an elevated risk of having a common condition due to shared behaviors, exposures, or interactions. In the case of sexually transmitted diseases (STDs), cluster testing can be effectively used to identify and manage infections within social or sexual networks. This approach allows for the efficient detection of asymptomatic or otherwise undiagnosed individuals by leveraging the interconnected nature of these networks, thereby facilitating timely intervention, and reducing the overall transmission within the community. It almost doubles the number of cases found.

 

Other Options:

 

In other 3 options the focus is more on finding individual cases and then case-based testing and diagnosis, not in group of individual/clusters.

 

Educational Objective

 

Case Detection in a STD Control Programme

 

  • Screening
  • Contact tracing
  • Cluster testing

questions.text: Warthin Finkeldey cells are seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rubeola

 

  • Warthin-Finkeldey cells are a type of giant multinucleated cells that are seen in cases of measles (rubeola).
  • Measles is a highly contagious viral infection caused by the measles virus.
  • The virus primarily affects the respiratory system and spreads through respiratory droplets or direct contact with secretions from an infected person.
  • Warthin-Finkeldey cells are thought to be formed due to the interaction of the measles virus with lymphoid tissue, leading to the proliferation of lymphoid cells and formation of giant cells.
  • These cells are characterized by a central mass of nuclei surrounded by a clear halo.

 

 

  • Warthin-Finkeldey cells are not seen in rubella, rabies, or typhoid.
  • Rubella is a viral infection that causes a mild rash and fever.
  • Rabies is a viral infection that affects the nervous system and is usually transmitted through the bite of an infected animal.
  • Typhoid fever is a bacterial infection caused by Salmonella typhi and is typically transmitted through contaminated food or water.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Rubella. Congenital rubella syndrome infection will have a triad of CCD, congenital heart disease (PDA), cataract & deafness.

 

Option C. Rabies. For rabies, there should be a history of hydrophobia with history of dog bite.

 

Option D. Typhoid. Typhoid fever will have rose-like spots on trunk on 7th day of fever, relative bradychardia, step-ladder pattern of fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Warthin-Finkeldey cells are pathognomonic giant multinucleated cells associated with measles (rubeola) infection and are indicative of viral interaction with lymphoid tissue, aiding in the diagnosis of this highly contagious respiratory illness.

choices.text: Primary Active Transport
Secondary Active Transport

questions.text: In a patient diagnosed with familial hypercholesterolemia, physicians are discussing the mechanisms of cholesterol uptake in cells. Which process among the following is relevant to cholesterol transport into cells but does not typically follow saturation kinetics in its uptake?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Simple Diffusion

 

  • Simple diffusion does not involve specific carrier proteins and is not typically subject to saturation kinetics.
  • Cholesterol molecules can passively diffuse through the lipid bilayer, but the rate of diffusion is not limited by carrier saturation.
  • Saturation kinetics is not seen in simple diffusion; while in active transport and facilitated diffusion, saturation kinetics is seen due to involvement of carrier proteins.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Facilitated diffusion involves the use of carrier proteins for the transport of cholesterol into cells and can follow saturation kinetics, where the rate of transport levels off when all available carriers are engaged.

 

Option C. Primary active transport involves the use of energy (e.g., ATP) to actively transport cholesterol against its concentration gradient and can follow saturation kinetics.

 

Option D. Secondary active transport (cotransport) utilizes the energy derived from the movement of another molecule, such as sodium ions, to transport cholesterol and can also follow saturation kinetics.Top of Form

 

  • Saturation Kinetics – After saturation of the carrier proteins and proteins used as pumps, symport or antiport, no transport takes place, i.e. they all follow saturation kinetics.
  • Both facilitated diffusion and active transport follow saturation kinetics due to the involvement of carrier or transport proteins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand the different mechanisms of cholesterol uptake in cells and recognize that simple diffusion does not typically follow saturation kinetics in its uptake due to its passive nature.

 

Ref: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 2nd South Asia edition, 13th Edition, page no. 36-39

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the clinic for a routine follow-up. She has been managing her diabetes with oral medications but reports a recent history of recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs). Her current HbA1c is 7.8%. You consider adjusting her diabetes management to reduce the risk of further UTIs. Which of the following anti-diabetic medications should be used with caution or avoided in this patient due to an increased risk of urinary tract infections?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Canagliflozin

 

Explanation: Canagliflozin is a sodium-glucose cotransporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitor, a class of medications that lower blood glucose levels by promoting the excretion of glucose through the urine. SGLT2 inhibitors are associated with an increased risk of genitourinary infections, including urinary tract infections, due to the higher glucose concentration in the urine, which can promote bacterial growth. In patients with a history of recurrent UTIs, SGLT2 inhibitors like canagliflozin should be used with caution or avoided.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Metformin: Metformin is a biguanide that primarily works by decreasing hepatic glucose production and improving insulin sensitivity. It is not associated with an increased risk of UTIs and is often considered a first-line therapy for type 2 diabetes.
  • Option B. Liraglutide: Liraglutide is a glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) receptor agonist, which promotes insulin secretion and reduces glucagon secretion in a glucose-dependent manner. GLP-1 agonists are not typically associated with an increased risk of UTIs.
  • Option D. Pioglitazone: Pioglitazone is a thiazolidinedione that works by increasing insulin sensitivity in peripheral tissues. It does not affect urinary glucose excretion and is not linked to an increased risk of UTIs.

 

Educational Objective: The educational objective of this question is to recognize the side effect profile of SGLT2 inhibitors, particularly their association with an increased risk of urinary tract infections. When managing diabetes in patients with a history of recurrent UTIs, it is important to choose anti-diabetic medications that do not exacerbate this risk.Top of Form

choices.text: Standard error of the mean
Standard error of difference between two means
Standard error of difference between two proportions

questions.text: A medical researcher is conducting a study on the effects of a new antihypertensive medication. The study involves sampling a group of patients from a larger population known to have hypertension. After analysing the data, the researcher is interested in understanding the variation between the sample mean blood pressure reduction achieved with the medication and the true mean reduction that could be expected in the general hypertensive population. Which of the following statistical measures would best quantify this variation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Standard error of the mean

 

Explanation: The standard error of the mean (SEM) quantifies how much the sample mean is expected to vary from the true population mean. It is derived from the standard deviation of the population and the sample size, providing insight into the precision of the sample mean as an estimate of the population mean. In the context of the research study, the SEM would be the most appropriate measure to assess the variation of the sample mean blood pressure reduction from the population mean.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option (b) Standard error of proportion: This is used when dealing with proportions, such as the proportion of patients responding to a treatment, rather than means.
  • Option (c) Standard error of difference between two means: This would be relevant if the researcher was comparing the mean effects of two different treatments or interventions.
  • Option (d) Standard error of difference between two proportions: Similar to option (b), this is used for comparing proportions between two samples, not for assessing the variation of a sample mean from a population mean.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Standard deviation of the sample is the degree to which individuals within the sample differ from the Sample mean
  • Standard error is an estimate of how far the Sample mean is likely to be from the Population mean

questions.text: A 68-year-old male with a history of hypertension and diabetes presents to the emergency department with chest pain radiating to his left arm, diaphoresis, and nausea. An ECG shows ST-elevation in the anterior leads, and he is diagnosed with an acute myocardial infarction (AMI). Fibrinolytic therapy is initiated promptly. However, a few hours later, he develops excessive bleeding from the intravenous (IV) catheter site and has hematuria. The medical team is concerned about the bleeding complications associated with fibrinolytic therapy and considers the management options. What is the recommended management for a patient who experiences excessive bleeding after receiving fibrinolytic therapy for an acute myocardial infarction?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Epsilon Aminocaproic acid

 

  • Epsilon Aminocaproic acid is an antifibrinolytic agent that can be used to manage excessive bleeding after fibrinolytic therapy.
  • It works by inhibiting plasminogen activation, which in turn prevents the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin, a molecule responsible for fibrin degradation.
  • This action helps to stabilize clots and reduce bleeding.

 

Explanation:


Option B. Protamine. Protamine is used to reverse the effects of heparin, not the effects of fibrinolytic agents. It would not be appropriate for managing bleeding due to fibrinolytic therapy.

 

Option C. Heparin. Heparin is an anticoagulant and would exacerbate bleeding in a patient who is already experiencing bleeding complications from fibrinolytic therapy. It is not used to control bleeding but rather to prevent clot formation.

 

Option D. Streptokinase. Streptokinase is a type of fibrinolytic agent used to dissolve blood clots. Administering more fibrinolytic agent in the context of bleeding would be contraindicated and could worsen the bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The question addresses the management of bleeding complications following fibrinolytic therapy in acute myocardial infarction.
  • Epsilon Aminocaproic acid, an antifibrinolytic agent, can be used to control excessive bleeding by inhibiting the fibrinolytic pathway.
  • Understanding the pharmacologic interventions available to manage complications of fibrinolytic therapy is crucial in the acute care setting, especially in the context of AMI.

choices.text: Diminished calcium in the sarcoplasmic reticulum
Antibody against the sarcoplasmic reticulum
Accelerated uptake of the neurotransmitter at the nerve-muscle junction
Antibody against presynaptic calcium channels at the nerve-muscle junction

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a history of small cell lung cancer presents to the neurology clinic complaining of progressive muscle weakness over the past few months. He reports difficulty in climbing stairs and getting up from a seated position. On examination, muscle strength improves with repeated use, particularly noted in the proximal muscle groups. Electromyography (EMG) reveals an incremental response in muscle action potential amplitude with repetitive nerve stimulation. Given these findings, which of the following best describes the underlying mechanism of muscle weakness in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Antibody against presynaptic calcium channels at the nerve-muscle junction

 

  • Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome (LEMS) is characterized by muscle weakness, autonomic dysfunction, and a paraneoplastic association, often with small cell lung cancer.
  • The fundamental pathophysiology involves the production of autoantibodies against voltage-gated calcium channels on the presynaptic terminals of the neuromuscular junction.
  • These antibodies impair calcium influx, which is necessary for the release of acetylcholine into the synaptic cleft, leading to decreased neurotransmitter release and muscle weakness that characteristically improves with repeated use.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Diminished calcium in the sarcoplasmic reticulum. This mechanism is not associated with LEMS. It is more related to conditions affecting muscle excitation-contraction coupling, such as malignant hyperthermia or certain myopathies, but not LEMS.

 

Option B. Antibody against the sarcoplasmic reticulum. This choice does not describe a known mechanism for LEMS or any other common neuromuscular junction disorder. Autoimmune responses in LEMS target voltage-gated calcium channels at the presynaptic terminal, not structures within the muscle fibre itself like the sarcoplasmic reticulum.

 

Option C. Accelerated uptake of the neurotransmitter at the nerve-muscle junction. This option does not accurately describe the pathology of LEMS. In conditions like myasthenia gravis, the pathology involves antibodies against the acetylcholine receptors on the muscle side of the neuromuscular junction, leading to decreased receptor function, but not accelerated neurotransmitter uptake.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The question aims to assess the examinee's understanding of the pathophysiology of Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome (LEMS), focusing on the autoimmune mechanism that leads to muscle weakness.
  • It highlights the importance of recognizing the unique clinical feature of strength improvement with repeated use, which is indicative of presynaptic neuromuscular junction disorders such as LEMS.
  • Understanding the specific target of autoantibodies in LEMS is crucial for distinguishing it from other neuromuscular junction disorders and guiding appropriate treatment.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with symmetric depigmented patches on the dorsum of foot, as shown in the image. The patches have well-defined margins and there is no associated itching or scaling. The patient reports that these patches first appeared several months ago and have slowly increased in size. On further questioning, the patient mentions using rubber slippers after which he noted these patches. In which of the following diseases is the chemical agent responsible for this presentation used as a treatment option in extensive disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vitiligo

 

  • The image shows depigmented patches that are consistent with rubber-induced chemical leukoderma, which resembles vitiligo but is due to an external cause.
  • In this case, the chemical mono-benzyl ether of hydroquinone (MBEH) is found in some rubber products.
  • MBEH can cause depigmentation by destroying melanocytes and is actually used therapeutically in extensive vitiligo to depigment remaining pigmented skin.

 

 

Michael Joseph Jackson (KING OF POP) before and after vitiligo images.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A) Piebaldism. This is a genetic condition characterized by a white forelock and stable depigmented patches present from birth, not acquired due to external agents like MBEH.

 

 

Piebaldism (White Forelock)

 

Option B) Pityriasis versicolor. This is a fungal infection that typically presents with hypo- or hyperpigmented scaly patches, not depigmentation due to melanocyte destruction.

 

Option C) Post-inflammatory hypopigmentation. This occurs after inflammatory skin conditions and is not induced by chemicals like MBEH, nor is it treated with such agents.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The clinical presentation of depigmented patches as shown in the image in the question is indicative of chemical leukoderma, specifically rubber-induced leukoderma, which can be caused by chemicals such as MBEH that are also used in the depigmentation process of Extensive vitiligo treatment.

 

Ref: Rook’s textbook of dermatology, 9th Edition, page no. 88.12, 88.45; Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition, Page no. 1094

Online resources: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3533321/

questions.text: A 27-year-old researcher is studying protein synthesis in a biochemistry lab. He is particularly interested in the role of transfer RNA (tRNA) in the translation process. During his research, he discovers that a specific amino acid is not directly incorporated into proteins by the usual tRNA-mediated mechanism but is instead formed post-translationally. Which of the following amino acids is he most likely studying, indicating that it does not require its own specific aminoacyl tRNA for direct incorporation into proteins during translation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hydroxyproline

 

Explanation:

 

Hydroxyproline is an amino acid that is not directly incorporated into proteins during translation. Instead, it is formed post-translationally by the hydroxylation of proline residues in collagen molecules. This modification is essential for the stability of collagen triple helices. Unlike the standard amino acids, hydroxyproline does not have its own tRNA or codon in mRNA and is not directly added during the ribosomal synthesis of proteins. This process highlights the importance of post-translational modifications in protein function.

 

Other Options:

 

  • B) Methionine: Methionine is one of the standard amino acids and is directly incorporated into proteins during translation. It is also the first amino acid in the newly synthesized polypeptide chain in eukaryotes, indicated by the start codon AUG.
  • C) Cysteine: Cysteine is another standard amino acid that is directly incorporated into proteins during translation. It is known for forming disulfide bonds, which are crucial for protein structure and function.
  • D) Lysine: Lysine is a basic amino acid directly incorporated into proteins during translation. It plays a significant role in protein structure, function, and enzymatic activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective is to understand the distinction between amino acids that are directly incorporated into proteins during translation and those that are modified post-translationally. Specifically, recognizing that hydroxyproline is formed by the hydroxylation of proline residues in collagen post-translation and does not require its own specific aminoacyl tRNA for incorporation during protein synthesis. This highlights the complexity of protein synthesis and the role of post-translational modifications.

choices.text: Mutations in 11q gene is implicated
Follows autosomal dominant mode of inheritance
Humoral and cellular immunodeficiency
Linked to adenocarcinomas

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding ataxia-telangiectasia?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Follows autosomal dominant mode inheritance

 

  • The mode of inheritance in ataxia-telangiectasia is autosomal recessive.

 

ATAXIA TELANGIECTASIA

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ataxia-telangiectasia is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the ATM gene on chromosome 11, characterized by defective DNA repair, immunodeficiency, progressive neurological degeneration, and increased risk of malignancies.

questions.text: Apparent volume of distribution of a drug is very high (6L/kg). Which of the following is true regarding the distribution of that drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sequestered in body tissues

 

  • A Vd (volume of distribution) of 6 L/kg means approx. 420 L (6 x 70) in a 70 Kg person. It is much higher than blood volume of 5L.
  • A high Vd suggests that the drug is extensively distributed beyond the blood and into the tissues.
  • This often implies that the drug has a high affinity for tissues, effectively getting "sequestered" or stored there.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Highly bound to plasma proteins. A drug that is highly bound to plasma proteins would typically have a lower Vd because it is mostly confined to the bloodstream. Plasma protein binding keeps the drug within the vascular space, preventing its distribution into tissues.

 

Option B. Confined to vascular compartment. A low Vd would suggest that the drug is primarily in the vascular compartment, including plasma and blood cells. A high Vd of 6L/kg indicates the opposite, suggesting that the drug is widely distributed in tissues rather than confined to the vascular compartment.

 

Option C. Sequestered in body tissues. A high Vd indicates that the drug is not confined to the bloodstream but is rather widely distributed throughout the body, including various tissues. This makes it the correct choice for this question.

 

Option D. Both A and B. Since neither A nor B are correct based on the given Vd of 6L/kg, option D is also incorrect.

 

Therefore, a high Vd suggests that the drug is stored or sequestered in various body tissues, making option C the correct answer.

choices.text: True hermaphroditism
46, XY intersex

questions.text: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia most commonly presents as:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Female pseudohermaphroditism

 

  • The most frequent enzyme deficiency leading to Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH) is a 21-hydroxylase deficiency, which typically manifests as female pseudohermaphroditism.
  • Female pseudohermaphroditism refers to the presentation of a genotypically normal female (46, XX) who has external genitalia that resembles those of a male.
  • The female is virilized, which means there is a masculinization of the body, and this virilization is usually evident at birth in females and within the first 2 to 3 years of life in males.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Male pseudohermaphroditism is seen in CAH due to 17-α-hydroxylase deficiency due to incomplete virilization.

 

Option C. True hermaphroditism is presently referred to as an ovotesticular disorder of sex development (DSD). Here, both ovarian and testicular tissue is present. It is not due to CAH.

 

Option D. 46, XY intersex (now called 46, XY DSD) has under virilization of genitalia. Adrenal causes include lipoid adrenal hyperplasia, 33-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase deficiency, 17-Hydroxylase/17, 20-Lyase deficiency, and not 21 hydroxylase deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Congenital adrenal hyperplasia, most commonly due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency, typically presents as female pseudohermaphroditism, characterized by virilized genitalia in genotypic females (46, XX) at birth.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following a high-speed motor vehicle collision. He is hypotensive and tachycardic with signs of internal bleeding. Immediate blood product support is deemed necessary, but there is no time for cross-matching due to the urgency of his condition. For the transfusion of fresh frozen plasma (FFP) to manage coagulopathy in this trauma patient, which of the following is the safest option without cross-matching?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) AB Rh D –

 

  • Fresh frozen plasma (FFP) contains the clotting factors necessary for coagulopathy management in trauma patients.
  • When considering FFP transfusion, the AB blood group is considered the universal donor because it lacks anti-A and anti-B antibodies, minimizing the risk of hemolytic reactions in recipients of any blood type.
  • The Rh factor is less critical in plasma transfusions than in red blood cell transfusions because plasma contains only minimal amounts of Rh antigens.
  • However, choosing Rh-negative plasma (AB Rh D –) is the safest option to avoid potential sensitization, especially in Rh-negative recipients.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. O Rh D + and Option C. O Rh D –. While type O blood is the universal donor for red blood cell transfusions due to its lack of A and B antigens, this principle does not apply to plasma.
